courses.name: Research Seminar for Literature Majors
courses.description: For juniors and seniors. Topics vary. Students research and complete an independent term paper related to the topic of the seminar.

courses.name: Senior Sequence
courses.description: For seniors preparing an honors essay in the literature major. Students pursue individual topics under the direction of a faculty adviser and the departmental honors coordinator. Admission by application. K grade given each quarter pending completion of essay.

courses.name: Senior Sequence
courses.description: For seniors preparing an honors essay in the literature major. Students pursue individual topics under the direction of a faculty adviser and the departmental honors coordinator. Admission by application. K grade given each quarter pending completion of essay.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Individual projects with faculty guidance. Open to majors with junior or senior standing and to senior minors. May be elected two times, but only 1 unit at a time.

courses.name: Principles of Entrepreneurship
courses.description: This survey-style class is designed for students with limited or no prior exposure to entrepreneurship. The class serves as the foundational course for the undergraduate minor in entrepreneurship, but is also a good choice for students who simply wish to familiarize themselves with the world of entrepreneurship. Students will be introduced to the requisite skill sets for advanced entrepreneurship coursework. They will also learn how to understand and analyze a broad range of entrepreneurial activity, and will have the opportunity to locate their own goals and values within the field of entrepreneurship.  Taught with IEMS 225-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Personal Branding
courses.description: Growing and Monetizing your Fanbase is designed to expose artists to entrepreneurial thinking in building their careers. Are you a singer, actor, musician, comedian, writer, graphic artist, fashionista, or dancer that wants to promote your career? Students will be exposed to highly relevant methodologies that startup entrepreneurs use to create and grow their companies, but in this case, the corporation being grown and promoted is their talent and fans, via their own personal brand.

courses.name: Storytelling for Business
courses.description: Humans have been communicating through stories for 20,000 years. They have the power to persuade, engage, and inspire action. But too often, in business, we don't think about harnessing the power of stories. Storytelling for Business will teach students how to use narrative techniques and structures to create compelling stories to help them nail an interview, motivate a team, secure funding, build a brand, and inspire customers.

courses.name: Engineering Entrepreneurship
courses.description: Overview of the entrepreneurial process from an engineering perspective. Idea generation, planning, financing, marketing, protecting, staffing, leading, growing, and harvesting. Business models for startups. Lectures, guest speakers, and case studies. Taught with IEMS 325-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Startup Accounting and Finance
courses.description: This class teaches students how to manage the finances of small and early-stage businesses using accounting software. Students also learn foundational accounting principles, and will work in teams on projects driven by case studies.

courses.name: Entrepreneurial Sales and Marketing
courses.description: Principles and practices for scaling entrepreneurial ventures. Application of coherent methodology to a student-run venture. Self-organizing teams develop a customer/client focus, provide for continuous improvement in successive iterations, and operate with transparency.

courses.name: Financing Entrepreneurial Ventures
courses.description: Topics selected from work of current interest in entrepreneurship and innovation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Innovate for Impact
courses.description: This is an experiential, team-based course in which students create social-impact focused entrepreneurial ventures using both lean startup methodology and human-centered design.

courses.name: Leadership, Ethics, and You
courses.description: This class is designed for students who want to explore how ethics and integrity are tied to leadership, and how developing leadership skills can contribute to students’ future successes in both entrepreneurial endeavors and more traditional careers.

courses.name: Entrepreneurship Demystified
courses.description: This is a discussion and project-based course in which students explore topics in ethics and leadership with the context of working for a startup or building one's own company.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.description: Topics selected from work of current interest in entrepreneurship and innovation. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Independent Study with Farley Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation
courses.description: Special projects under faculty direction. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: First-Year Seminar
courses.description: Open to first-year students in Weinberg College.  Does not satisfy major/minor requirements in EPC.

courses.name: Food and Society: An Introduction
courses.description: Overview of past and present food systems from a sociological perspective, examining the roles of culture, government policy, and social movements in shaping such systems and future alternatives. ENVR_POL 211-0 and SOCIOL 211-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Environment and Society
courses.description: Key environmental problems, such as climate change and oil spills; how they are shaped by the market, government regulations, and social movements; possible solutions. SOCIOL 212-0 and ENVR_POL 212-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: American Religion, Ecology and Culture
courses.description: The historical rise of environmentalism in American culture and its impact on religious thought and practice. ENVR_POL 261-0 and RELIGION 261-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: American Environmental History
courses.description: American history from precontact to the present, focusing on the role of the natural world in human history and the role of human thought and action in natural history. ENVR_POL 309-0 and HISTORY 309-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Food, Politics and Society
courses.description: Social groups, institutions, and policies shaping food production, distribution, and consumption around the world; their social and environmental consequences. Alternatives to existing food systems. SOCIOL 311-0 and ENVR_POL 311-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Social Change and the Environment
courses.description: The ways social patterns of production and consumption affect the natural environment, such as climate and biodiversity. Roles of social actors and structures in shaping environmental problems and policies. SOCIOL 312-0 and ENVR_POL 312-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: The Climate Crisis, Policies, and Society
courses.description: Examination of main impacts of climate change and of different perspectives toward mitigation and adaptation: market-based, institutionalist, bio-environmentalist, social movement, and climate justice. SOCIOL 336-0 and ENVR_POL 336-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Global Environments and World History
courses.description: Introduction to the recent histories of environmental issues around the world, including urbanization, industrialization, population growth, commodification, empire building, intercontinental welfare, energy extraction, and new technologies. ENVR_POL 340-0 and HISTORY 376-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Native Americans and Environmental Decision Making
courses.description: Focus on Native Americans, culture and cultural processes, and environmental decision making. Emphasis on contemporary Native American cultures and relevant research. ENVR_POL 356-0 and PSYCH 356-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Special Topics in Environmental Policy and Culture
courses.description: Lecture course on environmental issues of current interest to students and faculty. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Special Topics Seminar
courses.description: Seminar on current environmental issues and problems. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent project in student's area of interest. Readings and conferences. Comprehensive term paper required.

courses.name: Earth: A Habitable Planet
courses.description: Overview of the physical processes governing environmental systems, from lithosphere to hydrosphere to atmosphere. Physical science perspectives on current debates, such as those over water resources, energy, and climate change.

courses.name: The Health of the Biosphere
courses.description: Dimensions of the ecological niche; growth and regulation of populations; interactions among populations; community structure and diversity; conservation.

courses.name: Humans and the Environment
courses.description: Introduction to human interactions with the environment. Topics may include but are not limited to energy, sustainability, pollution, and climate change.

courses.name: Special Topics in Environmental Sciences
courses.description: Lecture course on environmental science topics of interest to students and faculty. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent research on special problems under direct supervision of a faculty adviser. Comprehensive report required.

courses.name: Principles of Finance
courses.description: Foundation course for the certificate. Basic principles of finance, focusing on the effects of time and uncertainty on value. First half emphasizes valuation, including discounted cash flows, equity and debt valuation, the term structure of interest rates, portfolio theory, asset pricing, and efficient market theory. Second half examines firms' financing decisions, including capital budgeting, capital structure, and payout policy.

courses.name: Investments
courses.description: Active portfolio strategies in bonds and stocks, optimal portfolio selection from the perspective of individual and institutional investors, and the role of style and performance benchmarks in portfolio management. Performance evaluation, trading costs, and other special topics.

courses.name: Derivatives
courses.description: Use and pricing of forwards and futures, swaps, and options. Strategies for speculation and risk management, no-arbitrage pricing for forward contracts, binomial and Black-Scholes option pricing models, applications of pricing models in other contexts.

courses.name: Topics in Financial Economics
courses.description: In-depth examination of selected issues in finance.

courses.name: Elementary French
courses.description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Elementary French
courses.description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Elementary French
courses.description: Conversation, grammar, reading, and writing for beginners. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intensive Elementary French
courses.description: For students with some previous experience in French. Review and development of skills in speaking, understanding, reading, and writing as preparation for work at the second-year level. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intensive Elementary French
courses.description: For students with some previous experience in French. Review and development of skills in speaking, understanding, reading, and writing as preparation for work at the second-year level. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intermediate French
courses.description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intermediate French
courses.description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intermediate French
courses.description: Grammar review, conversation, reading, and writing. Four class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intensive Intermediate French
courses.description: French language and culture: conversation, composition, reading of cultural and literary texts, and grammar review. Three class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intensive Intermediate French
courses.description: French language and culture: conversation, composition, reading of cultural and literary texts, and grammar review. Three class meetings a week.

courses.name: Intensive Intermediate French
courses.description: French language and culture: conversation, composition, reading of cultural and literary texts, and grammar review. Three class meetings a week.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Credit for 1 quarter only.

courses.name: Language and Culture
courses.description: Grammar, conversation, reading, writing, and culture study. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris programs. Students completing this course must take a placement exam before continuing French at Northwestern.

courses.name: Culture and Society
courses.description: Development of fluency, accuracy, and creativity in speaking, comprehension, reading, and writing French; introduction to social, cultural, and literary topics.

courses.name: Writing Workshop: Cultural Encounters in Contemporary France
courses.description: Practical study of French grammar and structure; students develop and improve writing skills through practice in preparing short compositions.

courses.name: Oral Workshop: Individual and Society in France Today
courses.description: Practical course to increase listening comprehension, build vocabulary and idiom use, and enhance communication skills.

courses.name: Acting French
courses.description: Use of dramatic scenes, dialogues, songs and performance to help students improve their language skills and develop their interpretive, interpersonal and intercultural competence at the Intermediate Mid/High level.

courses.name: Reading Literatures in French
courses.description: Introduction to texts in various genres such as essay, poetry, drama, novel, and autobiography, from at least two periods from the Middle Ages to the present.

courses.name: Reading Cultures in French
courses.description: Introduction to French and/or francophone cultures through texts and media from at least two periods; major themes, issues, and debates.

courses.name: Introducing the Novel
courses.description: Textual interpretation and analysis of short French novels from different periods, with special attention to formal issues.

courses.name: Introducing Theatre
courses.description: Textual interpretation and analysis of French plays from different periods, with special attention to formal issues. Principles of tragedy and comedy; contemporary developments.

courses.name: Introducing Poetry
courses.description: Textual interpretation and analysis of French poetry from different periods, with special attention to formal issues. Overview of major poetic movements.

courses.name: French Existentialism
courses.description: Existentialism in its literary, philosophical, and cultural manifestations.

courses.name: Theater in Translation
courses.description: Representative French plays from the 17th through 20th centuries; basic concepts of genre; social and historical context. Credit not allowed for both FRENCH 279-0 and FRENCH 272-0.

courses.name: Language and Culture
courses.description: Study of French language and culture in Paris. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris programs. Students completing this course must take a placement exam before continuing French at Northwestern.

courses.name: French Phonetics
courses.description: Development of near-native spoken French through practice in correct pronunciation. Phonetic system of contemporary French; introduction to basic issues of theoretical phonetics.

courses.name: Advanced Language in Context: Society and Popular Culture
courses.description: Practical study of structure, syntax, and usage of French through contemporary media, cinema, theater, and popular culture.

courses.name: Advanced Writing: Finding Your Voice in French
courses.description: Development of written expression for different communicative needs and functions based on the study of French writing styles and techniques.

courses.name: Advanced Conversation: Debating Contemporary France
courses.description: Development of advanced proficiency and confidence in spoken French through practice of speech and discussion of issues in current French media and culture. Emphasis on culturally appropriate usage.

courses.name: French For Professions
courses.description: French language as used in professional contexts. May include study of a specific field and differences from its American counterpart. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: The Middle Ages & Renaissance
courses.description: Study of literary texts of the French Middle Ages and Renaissance with emphasis on their historical and literary-historical contexts.

courses.name: Medieval French Narratives
courses.description: Major narrative works of the French Middle Ages in historical context. Content varies; may include epics such as the Song of Roland, romances such as Chrétien de Troyes's Perceval, and narratives of childhood. Texts read in modern French versions.

courses.name: Topics in Renaissance Literature
courses.description: Study of literary and other texts of the French Renaissance with emphasis on their literary, historical, and political contexts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Montaigne and Modernity
courses.description: In-depth study of the work of Michel de Montaigne and his models within the context of Renaissance history, politics and philosophy. All readings and discussion in French.

courses.name: 17th Century Literature
courses.description: Topics and issues related to the literature and culture of 17th century France. Content varies; topics covered previously include theater and its social and political contexts, the rise of rational thought, and the development of fiction and poetry. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Sexual Politics and the Ancien Regime
courses.description: Literary, intellectual, and political role of women in view of the debates generated by the issues of women's power in the public sphere before the French Revolution.

courses.name: Rousseau and the French Revolution
courses.description: Analysis of Rousseau's political thought and major literary works and their impact on Revolutionary ideology and culture.

courses.name: Studies in the Enlightenment
courses.description: Authors such as Rousseau, Diderot, Montesquieu, Voltaire, and Graffigny in relation to Enlightenment debates about science, religion, political authority, human nature, colonialism, gender, and slavery.

courses.name: The Novel in French
courses.description: Content varies; may include the novel of the ancien régime, the psychological novel, and the Bildungsroman in France.

courses.name: The Invention of Modernity
courses.description: Study of the origins of modernity in the 19th century, addressing such issues as the rise of mass culture, urbanization, and the beginnings of consumer society.

courses.name: From Modernism to Postmodernism
courses.description: Crises and reinventions of French prose from the modernist moment of the early 20th century to the ambiguities of "engaged" literature of the 1930s to postmodernism.

courses.name: African Literatures and Cultures
courses.description: Major issues, trends, and authors from francophone Africa. Content varies; may include Shahrazade, narratives of gender relations, law and literature, violence, and writing.

courses.name: Caribbean Literatures and Cultures
courses.description: Major issues, trends, and authors from the francophone Caribbean and its diasporas. Content varies; may include Caribbean women writers; slavery, history, and memory; Caribbean identities.

courses.name: The Maghreb and the Middle East
courses.description: Major issues in the literatures and cultures of North Africa and the Middle East. Content varies. May include exile in writing; politics of language and translation.

courses.name: France and East Asia
courses.description: Interdisciplinary approaches to the history of French-East Asian relations, including French representations of East Asia. May include translation, japonisme, cinema, literary and philosophical avant-gardes, and culture and globalization.

courses.name: Transnational Francophone Studies
courses.description: Exploration of cultural production in various genres from the French-speaking world, with an emphasis on themes, ideas, and/or forms that traverse national and/or cultural boundaries.

courses.name: Giants, Cannibals, and Critique
courses.description: Analysis of works of Rabelais and Montaigne and their techniques of satire and social critique. Readings include related selections from Erasmus, More, La Boétie, and others.

courses.name: Proust
courses.description: Introduces the works of Marcel Proust, a central figure of European literature and thought.

courses.name: French Film
courses.description: Topics in French cinema: for example, French classical cinema, the New Wave, postcolonial French film, the cinema of Marguerite Duras.

courses.name: Gender & Sexuality
courses.description: Major trends and perspectives in gender and sexuality studies such as first and second wave feminisms, lesbian writers, AIDS literature, queer theory, gender and orientalism, cross-cultural feminism.

courses.name: Contemporary Theory
courses.description: Introduction to some major trends in contemporary French theory and the way they have influenced literary studies in the United States.

courses.name: Topics in French Literature and Culture
courses.description: Advanced exploration of special topics in French studies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Political & Social Thought in France
courses.description: Major political and social trends in France from the ancien régime to the 20th century. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Women Writing in French
courses.description: Analysis of texts by women authors with regard to their respective social, cultural, political, and historical contexts.

courses.name: Gender & Writing
courses.description: Issues of gender and sexuality in the production of literary and other creative texts in various historical periods. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Topics in Literature and Culture
courses.description: Topics, issues, and questions in French and francophone culture. Content varies; may include French and francophone cinema, the intellectual in France. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Topics in Literature and Culture
courses.description: Topics, issues, and questions in French and francophone culture. Content varies; may include French and francophone cinema, the intellectual in France. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Translation
courses.description: Intercultural communication through analysis of translation theories and translated works; translation exercises. Content varies; genres may include prose, poetry, graphic novels, and theater.

courses.name: Foreign Language Teaching: Theory and Practice
courses.description: Theoretical foundation and practical applications of second-language acquisition and applied linguistics. Analysis and design of pedagogical materials. Self-reflection and analysis of teaching style and teaching philosophy.

courses.name: Advanced Studies in Culture and Thought
courses.description: Theoretical perspectives and paradigms for understanding culture through in-depth study of a historical, cultural, or theoretical issue or of a literary or artistic work. Independent term paper.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent reading and research. Topics arranged through consultation with an instructor and approval of the department.

courses.name: Sexual Subjects: Introduction to Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Survey of sexuality studies across a range of disciplines. Introduction to major theoretical and methodological approaches. Epistemology, morphology, history, subjectivity/identity, race formation, gender, social organization, and regulation.

courses.name: Traditions in Feminist Thought
courses.description: Introduction to milestone texts in the development of 200 years of British, European, and American feminist thought, with particular attention to emerging arguments and strategies around issues of gender and sexuality.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Representation
courses.description: Representations in art and literature within their historical, social, and political contexts. Theories of spectatorship, resistance, and revision.

courses.name: Sexuality & Society
courses.description: Examination of the role of sexuality in the cultural, economic, political, and social organization of the United States. Sex work, sex tourism, sexual migration, LGBT social movements, and moral panics. SOCIOL 232-0 and GNDR_ST 232-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Gender, Politics, and Philosophy
courses.description: Role of gender difference in the main political-philosophical traditions: social contract, liberalism, republicanism, socialism-Marxism, critical theory. Classics of feminist and political thought (Wollstonecraft, Mill, Taylor, Engels) and contemporary debates. PHIL 221-0 and GNDR_ST 233-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Language & Gender
courses.description: Exploration of socially significant differences in the language used by/about/to men and women, focusing on the role of language in constructing gender as part of local communities of practice. LING 223-0 and GNDR_ST 234-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Beyond the Binary: Transgender and Race
courses.description: Exploration of transgender history, identity, and expression, with a focus on the intersection of gender and race.

courses.name: Gender Issues in Science and Health
courses.description: Aspects of gender in the cultures of science and medicine.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and History
courses.description: Historical considerations of gender and/or sexuality. Topics may cover different historical time periods. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: US Gay and Lesbian History
courses.description: Gender, sexuality, and the rise of modern lesbian and gay identities. Lecture and discussion. HISTORY 324-0 and GNDR_ST 324-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Language & Sexuality
courses.description: The use of language to construct sexual identity, focusing on the language of and about gay men and lesbians. Topics include heteronormativity, identity labels and categories, gender versus sexuality, and cross-cultural sexual diversity. Taught with GNDR_ST 327-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Sociology of Gender and Sexuality
courses.description: Gender and issues of social reproduction and social change, with an emphasis on sexuality and reproduction.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Health
courses.description: Health-related topics concerning gender and/or sexuality. Topics include reproductive health, sexual health, HIV/AIDS, women's health movements, trans* health and activism and disability studies. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and the Law
courses.description: Examination of the changing role of law in governing gender and sexual relations in America. Legal definitions of gender and sexuality in the household, the marketplace, and the state. GNDR_ST 340-0 and LEGAL_ST 340-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Transnational Perspectives on Gender and Sexuality
courses.description: Studies of gender and sexuality in relation to globalization or non-US/non-Western cultures. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Research Seminar in Gender & Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Students research and complete a research paper or project on a topic of choice. Course number indicates distribution area in which a seminar counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Research Seminar in Gender & Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Students research and complete a research paper or project on a topic of choice. Course number indicates distribution area in which a seminar counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Research Seminar in Gender & Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Students research and complete a research paper or project on a topic of choice. Course number indicates distribution area in which a seminar counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Public Policy
courses.description: Studies of legal systems and public policy. Specific topics may include domestic violence and abortion legislation. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Political Theory
courses.description: Studies in political theory relating to gender and sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender and Citizenship
courses.description: Examinations of conventional conceptions of political participation and counter-public spheres informed by feminist activism and feminist and gender theory.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Literature
courses.description: Studies of literary texts in the context of gender theory, feminism, or sexuality studies. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Drama
courses.description: Studies in gender and/or sexuality in the context of theater and drama in or across historical periods. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Postcolonial Studies and Gender and Sexuality
courses.description: Postcolonial approaches to literature and theory. Topics include orientalism and diaspora theory as they relate to gender and sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Popular Culture
courses.description: Cultural studies perspective on selected topics in popular culture as they relate to gender and/or sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Performance
courses.description: Selected topics concerning theories of performance in relation to gender and/or sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Film
courses.description: Primary emphasis on representations of gender and sexuality in film and film theory. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Gender, Sexuality, and Digital Technologies
courses.description: Theories concerning gender and sexuality in digital representations, particularly Internet related. Content varies by quarter.

courses.name: Internship in Gender and Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Field research and practical work experience in activist organizations; biweekly meeting with the instructor and other interns for discussion of internship experiences and common readings.

courses.name: Black Feminist Theory
courses.description: Survey of black feminist theories. Content may vary by quarter. Fulfills the major's theory requirement.

courses.name: Queer Theory
courses.description: Survey of queer theories and methodologies. Fulfills the major's theory requirement. Content varies by quarter.

courses.name: Race, Gender, and Sexuality
courses.description: Literature and/or theory concerned primarily with the intersections of race and/or ethnicity and gender and sexuality. Content varies by quarter; may be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Topics in Gender and Sexuality Studies
courses.description: Topics vary. For example: masculinity; gender, race, and reproduction; gender, law, and public policy; Asian American women's history; women artists and their publics. May be repeated for credit with different topics.

courses.name: Senior Capstone Seminar
courses.description: Introduction to research methods in the interdisciplinary study of gender and sexuality.

courses.name: Feminist Theory
courses.description: Survey of gender and feminist theory. Content may vary by quarter. Fulfills the major's theory requirement.

courses.name: Senior Research Seminar
courses.description: Students work with an adviser and begin research on a senior thesis project, meeting on a reduced schedule over two quarters.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Individual tutorials or research projects.

courses.name: Engineering Freshman Seminar
courses.description: Broad engineering or interdisciplinary subjects of current interest.

courses.name: Engineering Dialog I
courses.description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

courses.name: Engineering Dialog II
courses.description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

courses.name: Engineering Dialog III
courses.description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

courses.name: Engineering Dialog IV
courses.description: Weekly seminar addressing subjects of interest in engineering, design, engineering policy, and entrepreneurial activities. For participants in the invitation-only Murphy Institute Scholars Program. May be repeated.

courses.name: Engineering Discourse I
courses.description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-1.

courses.name: Engineering Discourse II
courses.description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-2.

courses.name: Engineering Discourse III
courses.description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-3.

courses.name: Engineering Discourse IV
courses.description: Noncredit counterpart to GEN_ENG 195-4.

courses.name: Engineering Analysis I
courses.description: Introduction to linear algebra from computational, mathematical, and applications viewpoints. Computational methods using a higher-level software package such as MATLAB.

courses.name: Engineering Analysis  II
courses.description: Linear algebra and introduction to vector methods in engineering analysis. Statics and dynamics of rigid bodies and matrix analysis of trusses and networks. Engineering design problems.

courses.name: Engineering Analysis III
courses.description: Dynamic behavior of the elements. Modeling of mechanical (both translational and rotational), electrical, thermal, hydraulic, and chemical systems composed of those elements.

courses.name: Engineering Analysis IV
courses.description: Solution methods for ordinary differential equations, including exact, numerical, and qualitative methods. Applications and modeling principles; solution techniques.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis I
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-1.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis II
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-2.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis III
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-3.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Peer-Guided Study Group: Engineering Analysis IV
courses.description: Peer-guided study group for students enrolled in GEN_ENG 205-4.  Meets weekly in small groups, along with a peer facilitator, to collaboratively review material, work through practice problems, and clarify course concepts. Enrollment optional. Graded S/U.

courses.name: Honor Engineering Analysis
courses.description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-1 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

courses.name: Honors Engineering Analysis
courses.description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-2 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

courses.name: Honors Engineering Analysis
courses.description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-3 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

courses.name: Honors Engineering Analysis IV
courses.description: Covers topics addressed in GEN_ENG 205-4 at a deeper level. Intended for students with demonstrated strength in mathematics, computer programming, and/or physics.

courses.name: Analy/Comp Graph
courses.description: Introduction to AutoCAD, geographic information systems (GIS), and electronic surveying and measuring.

courses.name: Analy/Comp Graph II
courses.description: Introduction to AutoCAD, geographic information systems (GIS), and electronic surveying and measuring.

courses.name: Special Topics in Engineering
courses.description: Intermediate-level topics suggested by students or faculty members and approved by the curriculum committee.

courses.name: Domestic Study Affiliated
courses.description: Fulltime registration in an academic program in the continental United States that is affiliated with Northwestern. Upon successful completion of the program, registration is replaced with credits transferred from the affiliated institution.

courses.name: Special Topics in Engineering
courses.description: Topics suggested by faculty and approved by the curriculum committee.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Engineering
courses.description: Topics of limited scope as suggested by faculty and approved by the curriculum committee.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent study on an engineering subject supervised by a faculty member and concluding with a final report.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Language Study I
courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the introductory level.  Permission required in advance.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Language Study II
courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the introductory level. Permission required in advance.

courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the introductory level. Permission required in advance.

courses.name: Internship
courses.description: Restricted to Weinberg College students who need documentation of an internship on their transcripts. Requires approval of the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs. Contact college advisers for more information.

courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the intermediate level. Permission required in advance.

courses.name: Intermediate Topics in Language Study II

courses.name: Intermediate Topics in Language Study III
courses.description: Registration for students studying a foreign language through CourseShare at the intermediate level. Permission required in advance. Does not automatically satisfy the Weinberg College foreign language proficiency requirement.

courses.name: Arch Scholar Mentoring Program
courses.description: A weekly 1-hour workshop for first-year students in the Arch Scholar programs. Workshops will focus on academic skills, professional development, and college success strategies. Only two excused absences are allowed. Instructor permission to register is required.

courses.name: UPAL: Strategies for Advancing Learning
courses.description: Peer-mentored weekly small-group meetings about enhanced learning strategies. Time management, study strategies, interacting with faculty, and other topics.

courses.name: Science Research Workshops
courses.description: Learn about entering research with the help of a peer group leader and writing a research proposal for summer funding. Instructor permission or prior attendance at a Finding a Lab Workshop run by the Office of Undergraduate Research required. Grade of satisfactory given to students who attend and participate in at least 7 of the weekly workshops.

courses.name: Residence-Linked Seminar - I
courses.description: Seminar for students in a residential college or community on a theme of common interest. Meets in the residence and is directed by an associated faculty member. Enrollment is normally limited to 10 students. Proposals for seminars must be approved by the associate dean for undergraduate academic affairs of Weinberg College.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research
courses.description: Required registration for students receiving summer research grants from Weinberg College or the Undergraduate Research Grants Committee. Grade of satisfactory will be entered after final report is submitted.

courses.name: Student Organized Seminar
courses.description: Student-initiated seminar, supervised by a sponsoring faculty member. See Weinberg College Policies section of the Undergraduate Catalog for more information. P/N grading only.

courses.name: Study Abroad Affiliated
courses.description: Registration in an academic program outside the United States. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.description: Registration in an academic program outside the United States. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.description: Registration in an academic program outside the United States. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.name: Study at NU-Qatar, Doha Campus
courses.description: For Evanston-based Northwestern students studying in Qatar (NU-Q) for a term. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.name: Domestic Study - Affiliated
courses.description: Registration in an academic program in the United States that is affiliated with Northwestern. Upon successful completion of the program, appropriate transfer credit is added. Not for self-service enrollment.

courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.name: Non-Major Piano
courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.name: Non-Major Strings
courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.description: Class instruction in classical guitar.

courses.name: Non-Major Winds/Percussion
