courses.description: Audition required.

courses.name: Non-Major Private Voice-Beginning
courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.name: Introduction to Music
courses.description: Key concepts and contexts for becoming an informed listener and critical thinker with respect to a broad range of musical styles and genres and for acquiring the skills and vocabulary to discuss and write about music effectively. Individual sections may vary from quarter to quarter; see specific section descriptions for more information. No previous musical training or ability to read music notation is required. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: Selected Topics in Music Literature for Non-Majors
courses.description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: Selected Topics in Applied Music for Non-Majors
courses.description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

courses.name: History of the Symphony
courses.description: Study of music for the symphony orchestra from the 17th century to the modern period. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: History of Opera
courses.description: History of opera from its origins in Italy at the end of the 16th century to the modern period. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: History of Rock
courses.description: The basic elements of rock from its roots in pop, country and western, and rhythm and blues to the present. (VI. Literature and fine arts)

courses.name: Harmony
courses.description: A basic course in music theory fundamentals, including harmonic materials and tonal structures. Analysis of harmonic structures; harmonization of melodies. (II. Formal studies)

courses.name: Form and Analysis
courses.description: Nature of musical forms found in musical literature from renaissance to the present; analysis of musical examples.

courses.name: Non-Major Private Voice-Intermediate
courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.name: Western Musical Tradition
courses.description: Major genres and composers from 1600 to 1825. Primary emphasis on the generations of Bach and Handel, Haydn and Mozart, Beethoven and Schubert.

courses.name: Western Musical Tradition
courses.description: Major genres and composers from 1825 to the present.

courses.name: Non-Major Piano and Organ
courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.name: Selected Topics for Non-Majors
courses.description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

courses.name: Non-Major Private Voice-Advanced
courses.description: Private lessons for non-majors; audition required.

courses.name: Choral Organizations
courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.name: Band Organizations
courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.name: Contemporary Music Ensemble
courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.name: Orchestral Organizations
courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.name: Baroque Music Ensemble
courses.description: Non-music majors interested in auditioning for Bienen School ensembles should contact the ensemble director for audition information. Register under GEN MUS for 0 unit, or under CONDUCT for 0.5 unit.

courses.name: World Biogeography
courses.description: Geography of the world's major ecosystems based on the global climate model. Physical processes of soil formation and vegetation development in various ecosystems. Human impacts on natural systems resulting from past and present land-use practices.

courses.name: Atmosphere and Climate
courses.description: Nature and composition of the atmosphere, principles of atmospheric motion, global circulation model, cyclonic storms; climates and climatic change.

courses.name: Economic Geography
courses.description: Population, natural resources, land use, commodity production, and trade, with an emphasis on the world scale. Industrial location theory and global economic structures.

courses.name: Geography of Chicago & Its Region
courses.description: Chicago as an example and model of city form. Physical environments of the Chicago region and their influence on settlement. Evolution of the geography of Chicago and its suburbs from the 19th century to the present, with an emphasis on recent trends.

courses.name: North America
courses.description: Detailed study of the regional geography of the United States and Canada. The regional distribution of landform types. Patterns of culture, history, and economic development that underlie the distribution of distinctive lifeways in the two countries.

courses.name: The Human Use of the Earth
courses.description: Geography of the earth's natural environments as modified by human agency. Natural versus anthropogenic environmental change. Processes of habitat alteration in hunter-gatherer societies. Impacts of modern agriculture and forestry.

courses.name: Principles of Cartography
courses.description: Design, construction, and use of thematic maps for effective presentation of spatial data. Typography and symbolization. Coordinate systems and map projections.

courses.name: Geographic Information Systems
courses.description: Methods and techniques of digital cartography; encoding and analysis of spatial information; applications to archaeology, environmental sciences, and business geographics.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent research projects. Open to qualified advanced students with consent of department.

courses.name: Beginning German
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.

courses.name: Beginning German
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.

courses.name: Beginning German
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.

courses.name: Beginning German
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing-offers students a systematic introduction to German language and culture.

courses.name: Intermediate German
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic review of German language and culture. The class fosters learning in the four modalities: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Intermediate German
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic review of German language and culture. The class fosters learning in the four modalities: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Intermediate German
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic review of German language and culture. The class fosters learning in the four modalities: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Intermediate German
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic review of German language and culture. The class fosters learning in the four modalities: speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: German for Research
courses.description: Introduction to the translation of scholarly and scientific German texts. No prerequisites in the language.

courses.name: Intensive Beginning German through Musical Journeys in Vienna
courses.description: Interdisciplinary course offering musically interested students the opportunity to acquire German language skills through an immersion in the musical and cultural history of Vienna.

courses.name: Focus Reading
courses.description: Course for students who would like to explore German texts in more depth. Examines contemporary German culture. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Does not count for the language requirement. (This course will not count for the language requirement but may be taken concurrently with GERMAN 102-3).

courses.name: Focus Speaking
courses.description: Practical training in listening comprehension and speaking. Examines contemporary German culture. Does not count for the language requirement. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. (This course will not count for the language requirement but may be taken concurrently with GERMAN 102-3).

courses.name: Focus Writing
courses.description: Development of written proficiency in German through analysis and production of portraits, descriptions, narratives, reviews of films, reports, argumentative essays, advertisements, and interpretations of literary works.

courses.name: Focus Writing
courses.description: Development of written proficiency in German through analysis and production of portraits, descriptions, narratives, reviews of films, reports, argumentative essays, advertisements, and interpretations of literary works.

courses.name: Current Events in German Media
courses.description: Exploration of current events in a variety of German media (newspapers, TV, Internet, etc.). Topics include politics, music, film, sports, and literature.

courses.name: German in the Business World
courses.description: German language study oriented toward business-related communication situations, such as social interactions with customers, business travel, basic business letters.

courses.name: German Culture through Film
courses.description: Introduction to 20th century German cinema. Discussion of German identity, culture, history, and politics. Course emphasizes cultural knowledge and German language skills.

courses.name: History, Politics, and Culture in 21st Century German
courses.description: In-depth cultural and linguistic exploration of history, politics, and current issues (e.g., integration of foreigners, multicultural life) in Germany.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature: 1800-1900
courses.description: Introduction to representative texts and writers of 19th century German literature and familiarizes them with literary analysis and genres.

courses.name: Introduction to German Literature: 1900-1945
courses.description: Introduction to representative German texts and writers of the first half of the 20th century, when the First World War, the Weimar Republic, and the Third Reich marked the demise of the German Empire.

courses.name: Introduction to Literature: 1945-today
courses.description: Introduction to representative short stories by major German-speaking authors since 1945. The stories represent a dynamic period in German literature and highlight important social, political, and intellectual issues.

courses.name: German History from 1789-1989
courses.description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history from the consolidation of the nation in the aftermath of the French Revolution to reunification at the end of the Cold War.

courses.name: German History from 1789-1989
courses.description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history from the consolidation of the nation in the aftermath of the French Revolution to reunification at the end of the Cold War.

courses.name: Austrian Literature
courses.description: Overview and introduction to contemporary Austria-the land, its people, and cultural institutions-through newer writers such as Hackl, Handke, Haslinger, Helfer, Jelinek, Nöstlinger, Reichart, Schlag, and Turrini.

courses.name: Contemporary Germany
courses.description: The German political, social, and cultural scene after 1945.

courses.name: New Voices in German Literature
courses.description: Introduction to contemporary German literature in English translation. Topics vary and may include the contemporary historical novel, short story, novel, or memoir.

courses.name: German Film
courses.description: In-depth study of German films and cultural background. Topics may vary-for example, the pioneer film or "new" German cinema.

courses.name: Berlin and the Culture of Democracy
courses.description: History and culture of the city from 1900 to the present, including the Weimar period, Nazi regime, the divisions of the Cold War, and the newly unified capital.

courses.name: The Theme of Faust Through the Ages
courses.description: Faust theme in literature and music through shifting intellectual and social climates from the 16th century to the present.

courses.name: Jews and Germans: An Intercultural History I
courses.description: Exploration of Jewish encounters with German culture. German Jewry from the 18th century to the end of the 19th century, when Jews were granted legal standing as German citizens.

courses.name: Jews and Germans: An Intercultural History II
courses.description: Jewish culture-German culture exploration. German-speaking Jewry from the late 19th century to 1933.

courses.name: Kafka and Nietzsche
courses.description: Exploration of two key figures in German modernity. Analysis of the relation between philosophy and literature; inquiry into the idea of the "ascetic ideal."

courses.name: Turn-of-the-Century Vienna
courses.description: Literature and thought of fin de siècle Vienna and their impact on modern consciousness. Fiction, poetry, essays, and plays by Freud, Schnitzler, Wittgenstein, Hofmannsthal, Musil, Karl Kraus, and Schoenberg.

courses.name: Imagining Modern Jewish Culture in Yiddish and German
courses.description: History and character of Yiddish and the development of modern German culture and German-Jewish culture. Appreciation of the variety of "Judaisms" imagined and reimagined during modern European history.

courses.name: Analyzing Freud
courses.description: Freud's work from a comparative and interdisciplinary perspective. Fundamental texts by Freud in dialogue with related materials that situate him in historical, cultural, and intellectual context.

courses.name: Special Topics in German Literature and Culture
courses.description: Studies of a major author, a prominent theme in German literature or culture, a movement, or a genre. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Special Topics in German Literature and Culture
courses.description: Topics vary-for example, the fairy tale, Germanic mythology.

courses.name: Learning Diversity: Germany and Global Migration
courses.description: Explores how migration from and to Germany has impacted and shaped the country's political, social, and cultural development as an increasingly diverse country.

courses.name: Introduction to Yiddish Culture: Images of the Shtetl
courses.description: Analysis and discussion of the literary, visual, and filmic images of the communal life developed by Eastern European Jews and inseparably associated with them. GERMAN 266-0, JWSH_ST 266-0 and YIDDISH 266-0 taught together; students may receive credit for only one of these.

courses.name: Luther and the West
courses.description: Examination of Luther's work in the context of his life and times. Introduces basic dimensions of Western thought, showing how theology relates to broader cultural, political, social, and aesthetic issues. GERMAN 272-0 and RELIGION 272-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Speaking as Discovery
courses.description: A course to improve German listening and speaking skills to the advanced level. Uses current cultural texts, films, and television broadcasts.

courses.name: Writing as Discovery
courses.description: Practice of advanced and sophisticated structures of written German through a series of linguistic exercises, including a biographical piece of writing.

courses.name: German Media
courses.description: Current political and cultural events in Germany and Europe. Topics from German language media, including newspapers, magazines, Internet sources, and news broadcasts. Discussion of journalistic differences.

courses.name: Advanced Business German: the German Economy
courses.description: Germany's economy, its current problems, business practices, and differences from the United States.

courses.name: Advanced Business German: Marketing and Management
courses.description: Students gain skills to function in a multitude of German business contexts, such as management and marketing. They also increase their cross-cultural knowledge and intercultural competency.

courses.name: Reason, Revolution, and Despair: 1800-1900
courses.description: Discussion of key texts in German intellectual history from the Enlightenment to the prerevolutionary period in the 1830s.

courses.name: Myth and Modernity: 1900-1945
courses.description: Literature and thought, events, and ideologies that shaped German cultural, political, and social life from 1900 to 1945, during the Weimar Republic and the Nazi state.

courses.name: Recoveries and Transitions: 1945-Present
courses.description: Examination of the relationship of literature and film to the sociopolitical sphere since 1945.

courses.name: German Contributions to World Literature
courses.description: Topics vary-for example, Rilke's poetry; Nietzsche's influence on literature; Thomas Mann; Hesse, the German novel, and the mystic tradition; German intellectual history.

courses.name: Rhyme and Reason in German Poetry
courses.description: Introduction to German poetry from the early 18th century to the present. Concentrates on the main formal categories of poetry as well as the main topics and themes of German poetry.

courses.name: Modern German Drama
courses.description: Plays by authors ranging from Heinrich von Kleist to Peter Weiss, from the perspective of the stage as a "moral institution."

courses.name: German Cultural Studies
courses.description: Exploration of key concepts, major figures, and cultural and literary themes in German studies and interdisciplinary fields such as music, art, political science, media studies, and popular culture.

courses.name: German Expressionism
courses.description: German Expressionism in its most extreme literary and artistic reactions to the impact of modernity, war, and revolution and on the individual and collective experience in Berlin from 1910 to 1920.

courses.name: Brecht: Theater, Film, and Media
courses.description: Introduction to Bertolt Brecht's theater in the 1920s and early 1930s during the Weimar Republic. Historical critical review of the still-evolving media of film and radio.

courses.name: Shattered Worlds: Representation after the Shoa
courses.description: Examination of the role of German literature and art in the creation of historical consciousness in the postwar period.

courses.name: Literature of a Divided Nation
courses.description: Study of the literature and culture of the German Democratic Republic within social, political, and historical contexts.

courses.name: Writers and their Critics
courses.description: Study of the texts of leading writers in German through a discussion of the criticism these texts have evoked. Emphasis on 20th and 21st century criticism.

courses.name: Minority Voices in Germany
courses.description: Study of minority literatures in Germany (including Turkish, Italian, Afro German, and Jewish) within social, political, and historical contexts.

courses.name: Science and Culture in Germany
courses.description: Exploration of key texts popularizing major scientific innovations in Germany. The focus is on tracing the scientific, political, philosophical, aesthetic history of German as a "green nation" from the 18th century until today.

courses.name: German History: Weimar and Nazi Germany
courses.description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history covering Weimar and Nazi Germany. GERMAN 344-1 and HISTORY 344-1 are taught together: may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: German History: Germany Since 1945
courses.description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history covering Germany beginning in 1945 to reunification at the end of the Cold War. GERMAN 344-2 and HISTORY 344-2 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Topics in German Literature and Culture
courses.description: In-depth study of topics in German literature and/or pivotal periods in German culture.

courses.name: Topics in German Literature and Culture
courses.description: In-depth study of topics in German literature and/or pivotal periods in German culture.

courses.name: History of the Holocaust
courses.description: Origins and development of the massacre of European Jewry during World War II. GERMAN 349-0 and HISTORY 349-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Yiddish Culture and the Holocaust
courses.description: Analysis of modern Yiddish literature before the Holocaust as well as literary work that emerged from Yiddish-speaking writers who survived the Second World War.

courses.name: Undergraduate Seminar
courses.description: Advanced work through supervised reading, research, and discussion.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Open to outstanding German majors with senior standing.

courses.name: Introduction to International Public Health
courses.description: Introduces students to pressing disease and health care problems worldwide. The course identifies the main actors, institutions, practices, and forms of knowledge production characteristic of what we call "global health" today, and explores the factors that shape patterns and experiences of illness and healthcare across societies.

courses.name: Global Bioethics
courses.description: Global health is a popular field of work and study for Americans, but though entered with the best of intentions, the work is beset with ethical questions, concerns, and dilemmas. In this course, students will assess emblematic ethical challenges in global health and consider approaches to addressing them.

courses.name: Global Health & Indigenous Medicine
courses.description: Exploration of a variety of healing systems, their relationship to global health, and the factors underlying why people choose one over another.

courses.name: Biomedicine and Culture
courses.description: Comparative exploration of biomedical cultures in different contexts, both in the U.S. and other countries. This course covers how biomedicine intersects with technology, consumerism, politics, economics, culture, power, and place. It further investigates the possibilities and limitations of biomedicine across the globe, particularly regarding how biomedical cultures affect and are affected by patients and health care workers.

courses.name: International Perspectives on Mental Health
courses.description: Cross-cultural and international perspectives on mental health issues and examination of the impact of psychological illness on the global burden of disease.

courses.name: Global Health in Human History
courses.description: Exploration of paleopathology, including records of pre- and proto-historic adaptations to human disease, health, and medicine. The biocultural perspective on patterns of disease links past perspectives and current realities.

courses.name: Biomedicine and World History
courses.description: Introduction to the social, political, scientific, and economic forces allowing biomedical systems to become synonymous with global health governance. GBL_HLTH 309-0 and HISTORY 379-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Supervised Global Health Research
courses.description: Majors and minors are encouraged to do supervised public health research on campus and abroad. Students receive elective credit for this course only when taught abroad, however.

courses.name: Supervised Global Health Research
courses.description: Majors and minors are encouraged to do supervised public health research on campus and abroad. Students receive elective credit for this course only when taught abroad, however.

courses.name: Health Care Systems in Europe and the United States
courses.description: Provides students with an understanding of the various ways in which health care systems are organized in European countries, the problems they face, and the reforms implemented or proposed at the national and EU levels. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: Public Health in Europe: Issues and Policies
courses.description: Examines issues and debates on health policy in France and the EU, including primary health issues, health insurance, health inequalities, HIV/AIDS, SARS, elderly care, and genetically modified organisms. Lectures are supplemented by visits to relevant sites. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: International Organizations and Health: A Research Seminar
courses.description: Students design team research projects, learn about research methodology, discuss their research progress, and present findings. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: Health and Community Development in South Africa
courses.description: Health-related issues confronting South Africa, their social and economic impact, efforts to address them. Apartheid and post-transition policies. Demographics, prevention, and treatment of both infectious and chronic non-communicable diseases. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

courses.name: Public Health in South Africa
courses.description: Context of and responses to public health issues in South Africa, including HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis, malnutrition and poverty, psychosocial rehabilitation, and environmental and occupational health. Lectures are supplemented by visits to relevant sites. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

courses.name: Development Perspectives on Health in South Africa Through Community Engagement
courses.description: Reflection on service-learning experiences at community organizations in relation to theories of international development and global health. Focus on how health-related issues, including HIV/ AIDS, malnutrition, poverty, the environment, occupational health, and gender, impact development. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

courses.name: Qualitative Research Methods in Global Health
courses.description: This course emphasizes research skills acquisition in a practical manner. Topics include how to design, conduct, analyze and write up qualitative ethnographic research. The course covers research methodologies, ethics and Institutional Review Boards, and ethnographic field methods such as participant observation, qualitative interviewing, life histories, focus groups, data coding and analysis. Students acquire research skills while receiving significant feedback throughout.

courses.name: War and Public Health
courses.description: Comparative overview of the impact of armed conflict on public health and healthcare delivery worldwide. Historical and contemporary case studies. Specific health needs of refugees and vulnerable populations.

courses.name: The Social Determinants of Health
courses.description: Advanced introduction to socioeconomic, political, and cultural determinants of health disparities between social groups and categories. Case studies from the United States, South Africa, and Brazil.

courses.name: Global Health from Policy to Practice
courses.description: Examines global health and development policy, from the politics of policy-making to the impacts of policy on global health practice and local realities. This course highlights the histories and material, political, and social realities of policy and its application. The course draws on case studies of policy makers, economists, public officials, health care workers, and aid recipients.

courses.name: Volunteerism and the Ethics of Help
courses.description: Explores the ethics of altruism through the discourses and practices that make up volunteering, from the perspectives of volunteers, hosts, and a range of others both promoting and critiquing volunteerism. What motivates people to volunteer among strangers or in unfamiliar contexts? What are the implications for volunteers, and communities and institutions where foreign volunteering takes place?

courses.name: History of Reproductive Health
courses.description: This course concerns the history of human reproduction from multiple vantage points. Since reproduction is often about power, the course is framed around the distribution of power in matters of reproduction; as such we will pay particular attention during this class to struggles over matters of reproduction as we explore historical changes and continuities in reproduction globally since 1900.

courses.name: Public Health in China
courses.description: Examination of China's public health system. Focus on role of government, emerging environmental problems, food safety, and prevalent communicable and non-communicable diseases. Restricted to students in Northwestern's China program.

courses.name: Traditional Chinese Medicine
courses.description: Introduces traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) principles and methods as they relate to Chinese culture and philosophy, including TCM diagnostics and therapies. Compares and discusses integration of TCM and Western medicine. Restricted to students in Northwestern's China program.

courses.name: Special Topics in Global Health
courses.description: Advanced work in areas of developing interest and special significance. Can be repeated for credit with a different topic. Offered on campus and on Northwestern programs abroad. Recent courses include Ecology of Infant Feeding, Native American Health, and Public Health and Mental Health in Serbia.

courses.name: Special Topics in Global Health
courses.description: Advanced work in areas of developing interest and special significance. Can be repeated for credit with a different topic. Offered on campus and on Northwestern programs abroad. Recent courses include Ecology of Infant Feeding, Native American Health, and Public Health and Mental Health in Serbia.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Advanced work under faculty supervision. May be taken twice for credit but does not count toward the core or elective requirements.

courses.name: Elementary Greek
courses.description: Vocabulary, forms, and syntax of Attic Greek. Course one of three.

courses.name: Elementary Greek
courses.description: Vocabulary, forms, and syntax of Attic Greek. Course two of three.

courses.name: Elementary Greek
courses.description: Vocabulary, forms, and syntax of Attic Greek. Course three of three.

courses.name: Accelerated Elementary Ancient and Biblical Greek
courses.description: This is the first in an accelerated two-quarter series designed to teach students to read ancient Greek texts, from the biblical New Testament to Homeric poetry and Platonic philosophy. These two quarters will teach all the fundamentals of grammar and vocabulary and lead students directly into a course dedicated to reading the Greek New Testament, and classical Greek texts thereafter. Usually taught in the Winter.

courses.name: Accelerated Elementary Ancient and Biblical Greek
courses.description: This is the second in an accelerated two-quarter series designed to teach students to read ancient Greek texts, from the biblical New Testament to Homeric poetry and Platonic philosophy. These two quarters will teach all the fundamentals of grammar and vocabulary and lead students directly into a course dedicated to reading the Greek New Testament, and classical Greek texts thereafter. Usually taught in the Spring.

courses.name: Introduction to Greek Literature
courses.description: Review of basic grammar and vocabulary. Representative selections from Greek authors in their historical and cultural contexts.

courses.name: Introduction to Greek Literature
courses.description: Review of basic grammar and vocabulary. Representative selections from Greek authors in their historical and cultural contexts.

courses.name: Introduction to Greek Literature
courses.description: Review of basic grammar and vocabulary. Representative selections from Greek authors in their historical and cultural contexts.

courses.name: Introduction to Greek Literature: Intensive
courses.description: For students who have completed GREEK 201-1 or equivalent. Review of ancient Greek grammar and syntax and development of reading skills to prepare for third-year level. Four classes a week. May not receive credit for both GREEK 201-4 and GREEK 201-2, GREEK 201-3.

courses.name: Readings in Greek Literature
courses.description: Selected authors and topics. Topics recently offered include Homer, Plato, Aeschylus, Herodotus, Sophocles, and Thucydides.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Individual program of study under the direction of a faculty member. For advanced students only. Permission of department required.

courses.name: Hebrew I
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic introduction to mainly conversational Hebrew language and culture. Emphasizes the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Hebrew I
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic introduction to mainly conversational Hebrew language and culture. Emphasizes the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Hebrew I
courses.description: This sequence offers students a systematic introduction to mainly conversational Hebrew language and culture. Emphasizes the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing.

courses.name: Hebrew II
courses.description: This sequence further develops speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills in Hebrew. Offers also insights into Hebrew culture and history. Uses authentic written and audiovisual materials, including newspapers, short stories, poems, television, film.

courses.name: Hebrew II
courses.description: This sequence further develops speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills in Hebrew. Offers also insights into Hebrew culture and history. Uses authentic written and audiovisual materials, including newspapers, short stories, poems, television, film.

courses.name: Hebrew II
courses.description: This sequence further develops speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing skills in Hebrew. Offers also insights into Hebrew culture and history. Uses authentic written and audiovisual materials, including newspapers, short stories, poems, television, film.

courses.name: Hebrew III:Topics in Hebrew Literature
courses.description: Hebrew language, literature, and culture. Review of more complex grammar including the development of reading, writing, and speaking. Material includes authentic written and audiovisual works and newspaper articles.

courses.name: Hebrew III: Topics in Hebrew Literature
courses.description: Hebrew language, literature, and culture. Review of more complex grammar including the development of reading, writing, and speaking. Material includes authentic written and audiovisual works and newspaper articles.

courses.name: Hebrew III: Topics in Hebrew Literature
courses.description: Hebrew language, literature, and culture. Review of more complex grammar including the developemnt of reading, writing, and speaking. Material includes authentic written and audiovisual works and newspaper articles.

courses.name: Current Events in Israel: Israeli Society through Online News Media
courses.description: This course focuses on current events in Israel through in-depth exploration of online news media sources such as foreign newspaper articles and videos. Students will gain respect for alternative ideas and diversity of views and learn how news and public opinion are chosen, disseminated, shared. The course focuses on reading, listening, discussion and on building a comprehensive Hebrew vocabulary.

courses.name: Hebrew IV: Advanced Topics in Hebrew Literature
courses.description: Literature Reading 20th-century Hebrew literature. Presentations, discussion, and essays in Hebrew.

courses.name: Hebrew IV: Advanced Topics In Hebrew Literature
courses.description: Literature Reading 20th-century Hebrew literature. Presentations, discussion, and essays in Hebrew.

courses.name: Advanced Topics in Hebrew Literature
courses.description: Literature Reading 20th-century Hebrew literature. Presentations, discussion, and essays in Hebrew.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Hebrew.

courses.name: Hindi-Urdu I
courses.description: Beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari script only. Prerequisite - none.

courses.name: Hindi-Urdu I
courses.description: Beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari script only.

courses.name: Hindi-Urdu I
courses.description: Beginning college-level sequence to develop basic literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari script only.

courses.name: Accelerated Hindi-Urdu Literacy
courses.description: One-quarter course for speakers of Hindi-Urdu with no literacy skills. Devanagari and Nastaliq scripts; broad overview of Hindi-Urdu grammar.

courses.name: Hindi-Urdu II
courses.description: Intermediate-level sequence developing literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari and Nastaliq scripts.

courses.name: Hindi-Urdu II
courses.description: Intermediate-level sequence developing literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari and Nastaliq scripts.

courses.name: Hindi-Urdu II
courses.description: Intermediate-level sequence developing literacy and oral proficiency in Hindi-Urdu. Devanagari and Nastaliq scripts.

courses.name: Hindi-Urdu III: Topics in Intermediate Hindi-Urdu
courses.description: A series of independent intermediate Hindi-Urdu courses, developing proficiency through readings and discussions. Devanagari and/or Nastaliq script. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Hindi-Urdu IV
courses.description: Standalone course focused on literature and culture. Emphasis on reading, writing about, and discussing literary culture. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: For students who have advanced with distinction beyond the regular course offerings in Hindi Urdu.

courses.name: New Introductory Courses in History
courses.description: Introductory lecture courses on topics not covered in regular offerings. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Europe in the Medieval and Early Modern World
courses.description: Culture and structure of preindustrial society, high medieval through mid-18th century.

courses.name: Europe in the Modern World
courses.description: Impact of industrial and political change and development of modern society to the present.

courses.name: Jewish History 750-1492
courses.description: 750-1492: Political, economic, cultural, and intellectual life of Jewish communities under medieval Islam and Christianity. Judeo-Arabic culture and its critics; Jewish-Christian relations; the place of violence; rise and influence of Jewish law and mysticism.

courses.name: Jewish History 1492-1789
courses.description: 1492-1789: Jewish community's economic and cultural reshaping; legalized readmission of Jews to European cities and integration into European society.

courses.name: Jewish History 1789-1948
courses.description: 1789-1948: Plurality of models of integration, acculturation, and assimilation; multiple identities; split of traditional community; sociocultural behavior; political movements.

courses.name: History of the United States, Precolonial to the Civil War
courses.description: Interpretative survey from the 17th century to the present. Pre-colonial to the Civil War.

courses.name: History of the United States, Reconstruction to the Present
courses.description: Interpretative survey from the 17th century to the present. Reconstruction to the present. Lectures, discussion sections.

courses.name: Introduction to African-American History: Key concepts from 1700-1861
courses.description: African origins, the slave trade, origins of slavery and racism in the United States, life under slavery in the North and the South. AF_AM_ST 212-1 and HISTORY 212-1 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Introduction to African American History: Emancipation to Civil Rights Movement
courses.description: Emancipation to the civil rights era. Reconstruction, rise of legal segregation, strategies of resistance, migration, and urbanization. AF_AM_ST 212-2 and HISTORY 212-2 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Asian American History
courses.description: Introduction to the history of Asians in the United States, with a focus on their impact on American society as well as their experiences within the United States. ASIAN_AM 214-0 and HISTORY 214-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Global Asians
courses.description: Survey of Asian diasporas in the United States and elsewhere in the 19th and 20th centuries, emphasizing causes of migration, process of settlement, relations with other ethnic groups, and construction of diasporic identities. ASIAN_AM 216-0 and HISTORY 216-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Latina and Latino History
courses.description: History of Latina/os in the United States and in the context of US- Latin American relations from the 18th century to the present. HISTORY 218-0 and LATINO 218-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Global History: Early Modern to Modern Transition
courses.description: The early-modern to modern transition.

courses.name: Global History: The Modern World
courses.description: The modern world. HISTORY 250-1 is not a prerequisite for HISTORY 250-2.

courses.name: The Politics of Disaster: A Global Environmental History
courses.description: A global survey of key natural disasters from the eighteenth century to the present. Focus on the political and human-made dimensions of these supposedly "natural" events.

courses.name: Global History of Refugees
courses.description: Global History of Refugees Development of the international refugee regime in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries, including humanitarianism, international law, and activism by and on behalf of refugees.

courses.name: Background to African Civilization and Culture: Origins to 17th C.
courses.description: Historical approach to society, economy, polity, and culture in Africa. Agricultural origins to the 17th century.

courses.name: Background to African Civilization and Culture: 16th-19th C.
courses.description: Historical approach to society, economy, polity, and culture in Africa. 16th through 19th centuries.

courses.name: Background to African Civilization and Culture: 1875-1994
courses.description: Historical approach to society, economy, polity, and culture in Africa. 1875 to 1994.

courses.name: History of Latin America in the Colonial Period 1492-1821
courses.description: Aspects of the development of Latin America's socioeconomic, political, cultural, and religious institutions and practices. From the pre-Columbian and Iberian backgrounds through the colonial period, c. 1492-1821.

courses.name: History of Latin America in the Modern Period, 1789-present
courses.description: Aspects of the development of Latin America's socioeconomic, political, cultural, and religious institutions and practices. After independence and through the modern period, c. 1821 to the present.

courses.name: Sex after Shakespeare
courses.description: Sexual behavior in England between 1500 and 1800, concentrating on scandalous narratives and public controversy.

courses.name: Pirates, Guns, and Empires
courses.description: Piracy in the Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea, the Indian Ocean, and the China Seas from the late sixteenth to the early nineteenth century.

courses.name: Middle Eastern/Islamic Civilization
courses.description: Influence of Islam on the components of Middle Eastern societies (nomads, agrarian and urban populations) from the inception of the faith (7th century BCE) to the modern period.

courses.name: History of the Islamic Middle East: 600-1200
courses.description: The classical Islamic community; medieval Islamic civilization, 600-1200.

courses.name: History of the Islamic Middle East: 1200-1789
courses.description: Invasions from Central Asia and the empires that followed: Mamluks (Egypt), Ottomans (Turkey), and Safavids (Iran), 1200-1800.

courses.name: History of the Modern Middle East, 1789 - Present
courses.description: Jewish and Arab nationalism, oil diplomacy, Islam in the modern context, 1789-present.

courses.name: History of Ancient Egypt, 3100-c. 1000 B.C.E.
courses.description: The Old Kingdom: centralized government, divine kingship. The Middle Kingdom: new monarchic principles in the aftermath of social disorder. The New Kingdom: imperialism in response to foreign aggression; religious revolution of Akhenaton.

courses.name: History of Early Modern Science and Medicine
courses.description: The transformations of science and medicine in Europe and beyond during the period known as the 'Scientific Revolution' (c. 1500-1800). Focus on the social dimensions of scientific and medical knowledge, including the relations of science and medicine to religion, politics, commercial markets, and the expansion of Europe's overseas empires during the first age of globalization.

courses.name: History of Modern Science and Medicine
courses.description: The transformation of modern science and medicine in Europe, America and around the world over the past two hundred years; topics include the relations of science and technology from telecom to the A-bomb to biotech; and the relations of science to society, from Darwin to genetics/eugenics to climate change.

courses.name: Chinese Civilization
courses.description: Chinese history to the 16th century, emphasizing cultural and intellectual history.

courses.name: Sino-American Relations in the Modern World
courses.description: This course considers the bilateral Sino-American relationship in its larger global context and in connection to the issues of war, diplomacy, race, gender, religion, and material and popular culture. Focuses on the ways domestic politics shape international relations.

courses.name: Japanese History, Ancient & Medieval, 200-1600
courses.description: Ancient and medieval Japan (200-1600), from the first evidence of civilization on the archipelago through the Warring States Period.

courses.name: Japanese History: Tokugawa Period, 1600-1868
courses.description: Social, cultural, and political developments in the Tokugawa Period (1600-1868).

courses.name: World War II in Asia
courses.description: Analysis of the vast intended and unintended effects of World War II on Asia. Nationalism, global history, decolonization, fascism, Communism, democracy, and the experiences of ordinary people.

courses.name: Introduction to Topics in History
courses.description: Introductory seminar for non-majors and majors interested in a variety of topics related to a historical event, period, or broader historical problem.

courses.name: New Lectures in History
courses.description: Lecture courses on special topics not covered in regular offerings. Content varies. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: New Lectures in History: City and Civilization in the Eastern Mediterannean World
courses.description: Topics in the history of the eastern Mediterranean world. Restricted to students in Northwestern's study aborad programs.

courses.name: New Lectures in History: Milestones of Czech History & Civilization
courses.description: Topics in the history of the Czech Republic. Restricted to students in Northwestern's study abroad programs.

courses.name: American Women's History, to 1865
courses.description: Women and gender in American life, with attention to differences among women based on class, race, and ethnicity. To 1865.

courses.name: American Women's History, since 1865
courses.description: Women and gender in American life, with attention to differences among women based on class, race, and ethnicity. Since 1865.

courses.name: Asian American Women's History
courses.description: Exploration of race, gender, and the contours of US history from the perspective of Asian American women's experiences. Considers migration, exclusion, labor, marriage, family, sexuality, and cross-racial alliances. ASIAN_AM 304-0 and HISTORY 304-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: American Immigration
courses.description: Themes in history of immigration, especially from Europe, Latin America, and Asia. Law, racial formation, acculturation, transnational and international contexts, competing notions of citizenship. HISTORY 305-0 and LEGAL_ST 305-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: The American West
courses.description: Examination of the history of the American West as both frontier and region, real and imagined, from the first contacts between natives and colonizers in the 15th century to the multicultural encounters of the 21st century.

courses.name: American Environmental History
courses.description: American history from precontact to the present, focusing on the role of the natural world in human history and the role of human thought and action in natural history. ENVR_POL 309-0 and HISTORY 309-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Early American History: Conquest and Colonization, to 1688
courses.description: Conquest and colonization.

courses.name: Early American History: The Age of the American Revolution, 1688-1789
courses.description: The age of the American Revolution.

courses.name: New Nation: The United States, 1787-1848
courses.description: The early years of the new republic from the Constitution to the war with Mexico. Political theory, slavery, social reform, religious revivalism, westward expansion, political parties, the growth of capitalism.

courses.name: The Civil War and Reconstruction
courses.description: "Middle period" of American history, emphasizing origins of the Civil War, its revolutionary nature, and its immediate and long-term consequences for the South and the nation.

courses.name: The United States Since 1900: Early 20th C.
courses.description: America's domestic history and role in world affairs since 1900. Early 20th century.

courses.name: The United States Since 1900: Mid-20th C.
courses.description: America's domestic history and role in world affairs since 1900. Mid-20th century.

courses.name: The United States Since 1900: Late 20th C. to Present
courses.description: America's domestic history and role in world affairs since 1900. Late 20th century to the present.

courses.name: The Sixties
courses.description: Examination of one of the most tumultuous eras in US history, its roots in the reshaping of American society after World War II, and its legacies for the present. Emphasis on social movements of the period, particularly the civil rights movement, and political and cultural change.

courses.name: American Cultural History: 19th C.
courses.description: Changing values of the American people, how they have been transmitted, and how they have shaped American society, politics, and the economy. 19th century.

courses.name: American Cultural History: 20th C. to Present
courses.description: Changing values of the American people, how they have been transmitted, and how they have shaped American society, politics, and the economy. 20th century to the present.

courses.name: Legal and Constitutional History of the United States: Colonial Period to 1850
courses.description: Colonial period-1850. Development of legal institutions, constitutionalism, law and social change, law and economic development. Taught with LEGAL_ST 318-1; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Legal and Constitutional History of the United States: 1850 to Present
courses.description: 1850-present. Law in industrial society: administration, race relations, corporations, environmental protection, civil liberties. Taught with LEGAL_ST 318-2; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: History of US Foreign Relations
courses.description: Survey of US relations with the rest of the world from the 18th century to the present, with particular attention to the 20th century.

courses.name: The Fourteenth Amendment
courses.description: The Fourteenth Amendment's role in defining and protecting citizenship, privileges and immunities, due process, and equal protection from its nineteenth-century origins to the present. HISTORY 320-0 and LEGAL_ST 320-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: The Vietnam Wars
courses.description: Analysis of Vietnam's wars for national independence, with emphasis on US involvement. Topics include international context, political rationales, military engagements, popular attitudes, cultural exchange, and lasting legacies.

courses.name: Development of the Modern American City: to 1880
courses.description: City characteristics of urban society in America from the period of settlement to the present. To 1880.

courses.name: Development of the Modern American City: 1880-Present
courses.description: City characteristics of urban society in America from the period of settlement to the present. 1880-present.

courses.name: US Gay and Lesbian History
courses.description: Gender, sexuality, and the rise of modern lesbian and gay identities. Lecture and discussion. HISTORY 324-0 and GNDR_ST 324-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: History of American Technology
courses.description: American history through its material culture; industrialization and its discontents; consumer culture and household technology; mass communication and democracy; technological utopia and the computer revolution.

courses.name: U.S. Intellectual History
courses.description: Central questions in America's intellectual past from the colonial era forward; specific dates vary by instructor.

courses.name: Medieval Sex
courses.description: Fluidity of sex and gender roles in an age before "sexual orientation"; impact of and resistance to Christian theology's negative assessment of sexuality; the cult of chastity.

courses.name: Women in Medieval Society
courses.description: Examination of medieval women's lives in both secular and religious spheres through the different ideologies (religious, philosophical, scientific) that shaped them.

courses.name: The Development of Medieval Europe: Early Middle Ages, 300-1000
courses.description: Early Middle Ages, 300-1000.

courses.name: The Development of Medieval Europe: High & Late Middle Ages, 1000-1450
courses.description: High and Late Middle Ages, 1000-1450.

courses.name: The Age of the Renaissance
courses.description: Decline and revival of European civilization, 1350-1530. Cultural, political, economic, and social developments.

courses.name: The Age of the Reformation
courses.description: Europe in the 16th century, especially origins, evolution, and effects of changes in religion.

courses.name: Spain 1500 - 1700: Rise and Fall of a European Empire
courses.description: Social, political, and economic history of the largest early-modern European empire, its multicultural genesis, rise to domination in Europe and the Americas, and struggle to integrate internally.

courses.name: History of Modern Europe
courses.description: Survey of the political and social history of Europe between 1815 and 1945, with emphasis on the political integration and disintegration of the Continent and the causes and effects of social and economic change.

courses.name: Europe in the 20th Century, 1900-1945
courses.description: Growth of mass politics, fascism, the home fronts, rise of the welfare state, loss of empire, economic resurgence and integration. 1900-45.

courses.name: Europe in the 20th Century, 1945-Present
courses.description: Growth of mass politics, fascism, the home fronts, rise of the welfare state, loss of empire, economic resurgence and integration. 1945-present.

courses.name: Gender, War, and Revolution in the 20th Century
courses.description: Examination of changes in gender ideals and in the lives of women and men in Europe and America as a result of world wars, Russian revolution, fascism, and the Cold War.

courses.name: Paris: World City, 1700 to the Present
courses.description: Survey of the social, cultural, political, economic, and spatial development of Paris from aristocratic enclave to a class-divided bourgeois city, from an imperial capital to a postcolonial metropolis.

courses.name: History of Modern France: Ancien Regime and the French Revolution
courses.description: The Ancien Régime and the French revolution.

courses.name: History of Modern France : 19th c. to present
courses.description: 19th century to the present.

courses.name: Modern Italy
courses.description: Italy from the Enlightenment to the present, concentrating on the Risorgimento, the world wars, Mussolini and fascism, the postwar economic miracle, and terrorism.

courses.name: Weimer and Nazi Germany
courses.description: Survey of German political, economic, social, intellectual, and diplomatic history covering Weimar and Nazi Germany. GERMAN 344-1 and HISTORY 344-1 are taught together: may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Germany Since 1945
courses.description: Debates about the development of the postwar German states from 1945 to the present. Social, political, economic, and everyday history within the context of East, West, and unified Germany. GERMAN 344-2 and HISTORY 344-2 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: History of Russia: 800-1700
courses.description: Emergence of the Kievan and Muscovite states, 800-1700.

courses.name: History of Russia, 1700-1917
courses.description: Russia from Peter to the Revolution, 1700-1917.

courses.name: History of Russia, 1917-Present
courses.description: The Soviet Union and its successor states, 1917-present.

courses.name: East Central Europe under Communist Rule and Beyond, 1945 to the Present
courses.description: The history of East-Central Europe from the World War II to the collapse of Soviet rule and beyond.

courses.name: Christians and Jews
courses.description: Varieties of historical encounters between Jews and Christians. Origins of the "Jesus movement"; rabbinic attitudes toward Christianity; medieval polemic and engagement; the modern "Judeo-Christian tradition"; Christian Zionism and postwar ecumenicism.

courses.name: Jews in Poland, Ukraine, and Russia
courses.description: Social, political, religious, and cultural interaction of Jews and Slavs over a millennium, 1250-1917.

courses.name: Jews in Poland, Ukraine, and Russia
courses.description: Jewish encounter with Marxism and communism; social, political, cultural, and artistic aspects of Jewish life; Soviet Jews and the Russian empire: patterns of survival, accommodation, and interaction, 1917-91.

courses.name: History of the Holocaust
courses.description: Origins and development of the massacre of European Jewry during World War II. GERMAN 349-0 and HISTORY 349-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Global History of Death and Dying
courses.description: How death shapes the modern world via slave trades, imperial conquests, pandemics, wars, medicine, and genocide. Transformations in rituals; personal and social meanings of death; ways and patterns of dying.

courses.name: History of South Africa, Early Times to 1879
courses.description: From the African iron age to the establishment of the multinational gold mining industry, emphasizing the rise of African states and the contest for land with white settlers.

courses.name: History of South Africa, 20th century
courses.description: Emphasis on the 20th century, the rise of African nationalism, and the clash with the apartheid state.

courses.name: East Africa
courses.description: Selected topics in East African history.

courses.name: Topics in West African History
courses.description: Selected topics in West African history: economy, society, and government.

courses.name: Tudor and Stuart Britain
courses.description: Formation of the British state during the Tudor and Stuart dynasties, 1485- 1714, with emphasis on changing patterns of religious belief and the transformation of the monarchy.

courses.name: Modern British History, 1688 - 1815
courses.description: Social, political, and institutional history, 1688-1815.

courses.name: Modern British History, 1780-1900
courses.description: The Victorians: liberalism, empire, and morality, 1780-1900.

courses.name: Modern British History, 1900-present
courses.description: Empire to Cool Britannia, 1900-present.

courses.name: Gender and Sexuality in Victorian Britain
courses.description: Key debates and issues: prostitution, the city and sexual crime, sexuality and empire, sex and the single woman, homosexuality on trial, and the "scientific" writings of Victorian sexologists.

courses.name: Revolutions in Medicine
courses.description: Introduction to the history of medicine in the Americas from precontact to the present, with special focus on Latin America and the Caribbean in imperial, transnational, and global frameworks.

courses.name: Race and Nation in the Independence Era
courses.description: The process of Latin American independence, from the colonial background to 19th century insurgency wars, economic development, and nation formation, with emphasis on race and "the Indian question" in liberal thought.

courses.name: History of Modern Brazil
courses.description: Historical roots of modern Brazilian society: its rush toward economic modernization; radical social and economic inequalities; racially and culturally hybrid national identities; quest for effective democracy and universal citizenship.

courses.name: Revolution in 20th Century Latin America: Mexico and its Revolutions
courses.description: Mexico and its revolutions. Mexican history, from the modernizing regime of Díaz, through the revolutionary upheaval and the consolidation of a new regime, to contemporary problems.

courses.name: Revolution in 20th Century Latin America: Marxist Revolutions
courses.description: Comparative study of the origins and aftermaths of major Marxist revolutions in Cuba and South and Central America.

courses.name: Development and Inequality in Modern Latin America
courses.description: Examination of various models of economic development that have been implemented in 20thcentury Latin America, exploring the cultural, social, political, and economic roots of such policies and their impact on the region's poorest and most marginalized populations.

courses.name: The Ottomans: Last Empire of Islam, 1300-1622
courses.description: The Last Empire of Islam, 1300-1622. Emergence and rise to power; relations with other European and Asian powers; principal institutions; governmental and societal frameworks.

courses.name: The Ottomans: From "Second Empire" to the Age of Nationalism, 1622-1918
courses.description: From the Second Ottoman Empire to the Age of Nationalism, 1622-1918. Political and societal changes that shaped the modern Middle East and southeast Europe.

courses.name: Global Environments and World History
courses.description: Introduction to the recent histories of environmental issues around the world, including urbanization, industrialization, population growth, commodification, empire building, intercontinental welfare, energy extraction, and new technologies. ENVR_POL 340-0 and HISTORY 376-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: History of Law and Science
courses.description: The changing relations between justice and science-including the forensic sciences of identification and intellectual property-in the United States and Europe over the past 300 years.

courses.name: Biomedicine and World History
courses.description: Introduction to the social, political, scientific, and economic forces allowing biomedical systems to become synonymous with global health governance. GBL_HLTH 309-0 and HISTORY 379-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: History of Modern China: Late Imperial China, 1600-1911
courses.description: Survey of Chinese history from the rise of the last dynasty (the Qing) to the Revolution of 1911 and the inauguration of the Republic of China. Explores the transition from the “traditional” to the “modern” era and considers the transformation of social, economic, cultural, and international relations.

courses.name: History of Modern China: Twentieth-Century China, 1911-2000
courses.description: Survey of Chinese history from the Revolution of 1911 to the era of post-Mao reform. Course explores the political, social, cultural, and international challenges confronting China under the Republic of China (1912-1949) and the early People’s Republic of China after 1949.

courses.name: China in Reform: History of the Present
courses.description: This course examines the complexities of China’s reformist period from the late 1970s until the early 21st century. Topics include the transformation of rural-urban relations, domestic arguments about the unevenness and morality of socio-economic change, the 1989 Spring Democracy Movement, China’s “Peaceful Rise,” the AIDS crisis and SARS, and its growing participation in global affairs.

courses.name: The Modern Japanese City
courses.description: Social and cultural history of urban Japan.

courses.name: Japan's Modern Revolution
courses.description: History of Japan from 1830 to 1912, focusing on the overthrow of the Tokugawa shogunate and emergence as a modern imperialist power.

courses.name: History of Modern Japan: The Modern State, 1860-1943
courses.description: Japan: the modern state, 1860-1943.

courses.name: History of Modern Japan: War and postwar Japan, 1943-present
courses.description: War and postwar Japan, 1943-present.

courses.name: History of Modern South Asia, 1500-1800
courses.description: The early modern period, ca. 1500-1800: The Mughal Empire; the early phase of European trade and conquest in the subcontinent.

courses.name: History of Modern South Asia, ca. 1750-present
courses.description: ca. 1750-present: The age of British colonial dominance; the politics of nation building and anticolonial resistance; independence, partition, and the postcolonial predicament.

courses.name: History of Modern Southeast Asia Until 1945
courses.description: A social and economic history of Southeast Asia from c.1750 to 1945.

courses.name: History of Contemporary Southeast Asia Since 1945
courses.description: A social and political history of Southeast Asia from the end of the Second World War to the Present.

courses.name: Approaches to History
courses.description: Introductory seminar for history majors and others interested in understanding how history is thought about and written. Intensive exploration of a significant historical event, period, or topic.

courses.name: Research Seminar
courses.description: Students research and complete a term paper on a topic of choice. Required of majors.

courses.name: Thesis Seminar
courses.description: Advanced work through supervised reading, research, and discussion. Admission by written application, to be reviewed by department. Grade of K given in 398-1 and 398-2.

courses.name: Thesis Seminar
courses.description: Advanced work through supervised reading, research, and discussion. Admission by written application, to be reviewed by department. Grade of K given in 398-1 and 398-2.

courses.name: Thesis Seminar
courses.description: Advanced work through supervised reading, research, and discussion. Admission by written application, to be reviewed by department. Grade of K given in 398-1 and 398-2.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Reading and conferences on special subjects for advanced undergraduates. Open only with consent of director of undergraduate studies and instructor.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Reading and conferences on special subjects for advanced undergraduates. Open only with consent of director of undergraduate studies and instructor.

courses.name: The Counseling Process:  Theory & Practice
courses.description: Survey of counseling perspectives and techniques, along with the theories that form the basis of understanding these concepts.  Overview of clinical assessment, client systems, counseling theories, and counseling techniques. Review how dynamics and complexity associated with counseling diverse populations and understanding the roles that diversity and personal values play in the counseling process.

courses.name: Identity and Motivation
courses.description: Examines the connection between conceptions of the self and goal-oriented motivation, with particular attention to the influence of social, structural, and cultural forces.

courses.name: Emotional Mysteries
courses.description: Classrooms, work settings, and family relations are hotbeds of emotion. But what is an emotion? What happens in our bodies when an emotion is triggered? How can emotions help us live productive, healthy, and connected lives? And can we ever truly understand what somebody else is feeling? These are some of the mysteries that we will seek to unravel in this course. We will read literature from Darwin to the latest scientific studies, combine lectures and small-group discussions, conduct research experiments, and engage in peer review and online collaboration.

courses.name: Team Dynamics
courses.description: In this course, we will explore team dynamics, those forces that influence a team's behavior and performance, and what can enhance or hinder potential for impact. We will analyze the contributors to team functioning and their interrelationships at multiple levels: intrapersonal, interpersonal, group and organizational. Key topics include team development, team make-up and roles, leadership and followership, decision-making, navigating conflict, collaboration and competition, effective communication, content vs. process, diversity and in-group/out-group tensions. Throughout the class, students will be analyzing and applying concepts through case studies and simulations. Assignments to demonstrate mastery include regular written individual papers and a team project. This course is suitable for undergraduate students in LOC, Human Development in Context, and related majors throughout Northwestern that are interested in leadership, teams/groups or organizational change. Taught with LOC 309-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: The Art and Science of Aging
courses.description: For over 2000 years, poets and philosophers have commented on the universal human experience of "getting older."  In the past few hundred years, novelists and scientists have joined the effort, along with filmmakers, musicians, counselors, bloggers, motivational speakers, and a host of others.  What does it feel like to move through the adult years and toward "old age"?  How do people's personalities, social relationships, and overall world view change as they grow older?  What does psychological and social science have to say about general trends, as well as individual differences, in aging?  This discussion-based and writing-intensive seminar is sequentially organized in terms of five cardinal themes:  (1) the social/emotional world, (2) generations, (3) memory and the self,  (4) loss, and (5) wisdom of the ages.  Within these five themes, the seminar will consider a range of psychological and social issues as they apply to adult development and aging, sampling some of the most provocative sources from fiction, drama, poetry, music, and cinema - and from the scientific literature.

courses.name: Building Loving and Lasting Relationships: Marriage 101
courses.description: The intricacies and problems of close, committed, interpersonal relationships, especially marriage. Open to first-year students.

courses.name: Special Topics in Human Development in Context
courses.description: Advanced work on special topics.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: SEE DEPT FOR SECTION AND PERMISSION NUMBERS.

courses.name: Introduction to Critical Thinking in the Humanities and Social Sciences
courses.description: For participants in Bridge I summer program.  Commonalities and distinguishing features of critical thinking in humanities and social sciences. Emphasis on analysis and argumentation.  Taken with MATH 100-BR.

courses.name: Asking - and Answering - Questions in the Humanities and Social Sciences
courses.description: For participants in Bridge I summer program.  How to determine the appropriate scope of a research paper, how to begin research, and related skills in humanities and social sciences.

courses.name: First-Year Seminar
courses.description: Part of a two-course exploration of the humanities for first-year students selected into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program. This team-taught program—lecture + small coordinated seminar—is designed to challenge students to integrate a variety of intellectual methods to probe the qualitative aspects of human experience. Course topics and instructors change each year. HUM 101-6 is the lecture section (2 days/week) and HUM 210-0 is the paired seminar section (2 days/week).

courses.name: The Humanities Plunge
courses.description: A half-credit course over spring break immersing students in Chicago's cultural riches. Events and tours are introduced and contextualized by field experts. Enrollment in the Plunge is by application.

courses.name: The World of Homer
courses.description: Introduction to the history and material culture of Iron Age Greece. Society, economy, art, and archaeology of the Greek world that gave rise to the Homeric epic. CLASSICS 210-0 and HUM 205-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Humanities in the World I
courses.description: Part of a two-course exploration of the humanities for first-year students selected into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program. This team-taught program—lecture + small coordinated seminar—is designed to challenge students to integrate a variety of intellectual methods to probe the qualitative aspects of human experience. Course topics and instructors change each year. HUM 101-6 is the lecture section (2 days/week) and HUM 210-0 is the paired seminar section (2 days/week).

courses.name: Humanities in the World II
courses.description: Part of a two-course exploration of the humanities for first-year students selected into the Kaplan Humanities Scholars Program. This team-taught program—lecture + small coordinated seminar—is designed to challenge students to integrate a variety of intellectual methods to probe the qualitative aspects of human experience. Course topics and instructors change each year. HUM 101-6 is the lecture section (2 days/week) and HUM 211-0 is the paired seminar section (2 days/week).

courses.name: Health, Biomedicine, Culture, and Society
courses.description: Broad introduction to controversies surrounding health and biomedicine by analyzing culture, politics, values, and social institutions. HUM 220-0 and SOCIOL 220-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Media Theory
courses.description: Comprehensive introduction from a humanistic perspective to theories about the nature of media and the role of technology in modern culture. ART_HIST 375-0 and HUM 225-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Humanities Explorations
courses.description: Lecture course, often team-taught, that explores social, ethical, and political big questions-e.g., the nature of love, the value of reading, relativity in science and culture, ways to model "choice" across the humanities-from different disciplinary perspectives. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Global Humanities Lab
courses.description: Investigation of an international humanities topic through experiential learning and offsite research; focus on how different cultures process and understand the artifacts of human cultures and their values. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.description: Investigation of an international humanities topic through experiential learning and offsite research; focus on how different cultures process and understand the artifacts of human cultures and their values. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.description: Investigation of an international humanities topic through experiential learning and offsite research; focus on how different cultures process and understand the artifacts of human cultures and their values. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Humanities in the Digital Age
courses.description: Innovative and collaborative ways to incorporate technology into humanistic study. Ways to digitize text, image, sound, and/ or video for analysis. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Humanities in the Digital Age
courses.description: Innovative and collaborative ways to incorporate technology into humanistic study. Ways to digitize text, image, sound, and/ or video for analysis. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Humanities in the Digital Age
courses.description: Innovative and collaborative ways to incorporate technology into humanistic study. Ways to digitize text, image, sound, and/ or video for analysis. Course number indicates distribution requirement area in which a course counts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.
