Although the topic can change, it is expected that independent of the content, this is an advanced physics course that builds on core physics knowledge. Prerequisites vary by offering. It would generally require knowledge of at least one core physics course (Physics 330, 332, 333, 339) or the equivalent mathematics or Permission from Instructor.

courses.name: Independent Thesis Research
courses.description: Individual study under the direction of a faculty member. Open only to advanced students pursuing departmental honors.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Opportunity to study an advanced subject of interest under the individual direction of a faculty member. Open to all advanced students; consent of instructor required.

courses.name: Piano Repertoire I
courses.description: Analytical and historical study of piano solo and concerto repertoire from early keyboard literature to the present.

courses.name: Piano Repertoire II
courses.description: Analytical and historical study of piano solo and concerto repertoire from early keyboard literature to the present.

courses.name: Piano Repertoire III
courses.description: Analytical and historical study of piano solo and concerto repertoire from early keyboard literature to the present.

courses.name: Piano Pedagogy I
courses.description: Lecture/demonstration/laboratory course in piano teaching at all levels. Principles and techniques of group and individual instruction; survey of teaching materials. Seniors and graduate students.

courses.name: Piano Pedagogy II
courses.description: Lecture/demonstration/laboratory course in piano teaching at all levels. Principles and techniques of group and individual instruction; survey of teaching materials. Seniors and graduate students.

courses.name: Piano Pedagogy III
courses.description: Lecture/demonstration/laboratory course in piano teaching at all levels. Principles and techniques of group and individual instruction; survey of teaching materials. Seniors and graduate students.

courses.name: Collaborative Piano-Beginning I
courses.description: Piano students work with a singer and instrumentalist in the preparation and performance of mainstream recital repertoire.

courses.name: Collaborative Piano-Beginning II
courses.description: Piano students work with a singer and instrumentalist in the preparation and performance of mainstream recital repertoire.

courses.name: Collaborative Piano-Beginning III
courses.description: Piano students work with a singer and instrumentalist in the preparation and performance of mainstream recital repertoire.

courses.name: Duo Class
courses.description: Provides an opportunity for pianists and their vocal and/or instrumental partners to receive intensive coaching on works of their choice. A final performance is required.

courses.name: Selected Topics
courses.description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

courses.name: Repertoire Studies
courses.description: Topics vary by quarter.

courses.name: Elementary Polish
courses.description: Polish language and culture. Basic reading, writing, listening, and speaking. No prerequisite.

courses.name: Elementary Polish
courses.description: Polish language and culture. Basic reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

courses.name: Elementary Polish
courses.description: Polish language and culture. Basic reading, writing, listening, and speaking.

courses.name: Intermediate Polish: Language and Culture
courses.description: Reading on topics in Polish culture and society.

courses.name: Intermediate Polish: Language and Culture
courses.description: Reading on topics in Polish culture and society.

courses.name: Intermediate Polish: Language and Culture
courses.description: Reading on topics in Polish culture and society.

courses.name: Polish for Advanced and Native Speakers
courses.description: Polish for advanced speakers, including those who grew up in the United States. Stress on advanced levels of reading and writing as well as speaking. Taught entirely in Polish. Content varies; may be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Polish for Advanced and Native Speakers
courses.description: Polish for advanced speakers, including those who grew up in the United States. Stress on advanced levels of reading and writing as well as speaking. Taught entirely in Polish. Content varies; may be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Introduction to Political Theory
courses.description: Examination of texts in political theory. Topics vary but often include justice, the Greek polis, the modern state, individualism, representative democracy.

courses.name: Introduction to Empirical Methods in Political Science
courses.description: Tools political scientists use. How qualitative, quantitative, and experimental research designs help answer difficult descriptive and causal questions.

courses.name: Introduction to Interpretive Methods in Political Science
courses.description: Philosophy of inquiry and interpretive research methods for students of political science. Examines diverse schools of thought on research methods and their relevance for research goals.

courses.name: Evaluating Evidence
courses.description: Introduction to evaluation of qualitative and quantitative evidence across science, politics, society, health, education, and industry. POLI_SCI 212-0 and COG_SCI 202-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: American Government and Politics
courses.description: The structure and process of American politics from competing perspectives. Analysis of representation, voting, interest groups, parties, leadership, and policymaking institutions. The gateway course for the American politics subfield.

courses.name: Introduction to Law in the Political Arena
courses.description: Roles of law in society and politics. Police and prisons, law and social change, courts and politics, legal reasoning, Supreme Court decision making, judicial discretion, legal strategies for making change.

courses.name: Introduction to International Relations
courses.description: Introduction to the major theories, concepts, and problems of contemporary international relations. Security, political economy, and cooperation.

courses.name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
courses.description: Emphasis may be on industrialized and/or developing states. Major issues include regime-society relations, political change and conflict, and policy making.

courses.name: Classical Political Theory
courses.description: Political thought of Greece and Rome in historical context and with attention to contemporary theoretical interest.

courses.name: Subjects, Citizens, Revolutionaries: Early Modern Political Thought
courses.description: Political philosophers from the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries. Topics include sources of power and their impact on justice, equality, and law. No prerequisites, but some knowledge of political theory is desirable.

courses.name: Modernity and Its Discontents
courses.description: Examination of late 19th and early 20th century social and political thought in the works of writers such as Marx, Weber, Mill, Kafka, Darwin, Nietzsche, Freud, and de Beauvoir. No prerequisites, but some knowledge of political theory is desirable.

courses.name: Human Rights Between East and West
courses.description: In this course, students consider challenges leveled against the declared universalism of human rights. They assess these challenges from the perspective of two non-western traditions: Islam and Confucianism.

courses.name: American Political Thought
courses.description: Advanced introduction to the development of political thought in the United States from the revolutionaries to the 20th century pragmatists.

courses.name: Deportation Law and Politics
courses.description: Analysis of deportation law and politics from colonial America through today. Requires two visits to Chicago immigration courts.

courses.name: Critical Theory and the Study of Politics
courses.description: Critical theory examines and contests hegemonic thinking about politics and envisages alternate worlds of political possibility. Note: students cannot receive credit for both POLI_SCI 308-0 (Evanston) and POLI_SCI 308-SA (study abroad).

courses.name: Critical Theory and the Study of Politics
courses.description: Critical theory examines and contests hegemonic thinking about politics and envisages alternate worlds of political possibility. This study abroad course is restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program in critical theory, literature, and media.

courses.name: Political Theories of the Rule of Law
courses.description: Key documents and debates in the development of theories of law and jurisprudence. From Aeschylus to contemporary democratic and legal theories and major court cases on topics ranging from torture to Title IX. POLI_SCI 309-0 and LEGAL_ST 309-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Methods of Political Inference
courses.description: Methods for inferences based on data in political research. Research design and quantitative and qualitative methods of inference. Focuses on descriptive, statistical, and causal inference and the application of different methods to substantive problems.

courses.name: Logics of Political Inquiry
courses.description: Political science as "science." Identity sources, construction, functions, and validation of social science theory and explanation from varied perspectives.

courses.name: Statistical Research Methods
courses.description: Intermediate coverage of statistical methods appropriate for data in political science research, such as multiple regression, logit and probit, estimation and inference with non-independent or non-identically distributed sampling, basic time series and panel data methods, and causal inference in statistical models.

courses.name: The American Presidency
courses.description: Structural foundations and historical development of the American presidency; predominant scholarly theories of presidential power and leadership; contemporary issues and debates.

courses.name: Urban Politics
courses.description: Structure of local and regional political power and its relation to the social and economic structure of community.

courses.name: Ideas and Institutions in Urban Politics
courses.description: Advanced urban politics. Analyzes opportunities for action in local politics and challenges for effective governance in the modern metropolis.

courses.name: Public Opinion and Voting Behavior
courses.description: Who votes and for whom. Social, psychological, economic, and political factors influencing election choices. Sources of opinions. Focus on American presidential elections with some comparative and nonpresidential material.

courses.name: Political Parties and Elections
courses.description: Role of political parties in a democratic society. Topics include nomination, national conventions, political funding, campaigns, party organization, and national, state, and local parties.

courses.name: Congress and the Legislative Process
courses.description: Organization of legislatures to make public policy; impact of constituents and political parties on legislative decision making; polarization; legislative-executive relations. Emphasis on the US Congress and contemporary politics.

courses.name: Race and Public Policy
courses.description: Analysis of how diversity shapes policy in the United States and how policies contribute to racial and ethnic diversity. Immigration reform, school choice, residential segregation, and criminal justice.

courses.name: African American Politics
courses.description: Survey of black politics in the United States, including blacks' relations with government, whites, political parties, public policy, and electoral politics.

courses.name: Public Policy
courses.description: The role of government in regulating economic and social behavior; theories of public policy making; sources and effects of public policy.

courses.name: U.S. Environmental Politics
courses.description: Political problems associated with human impact on natural environment; pollution, natural resources, public lands, land use, energy, and population.

courses.name: U.S. Refugee Policy & Localities
courses.description: Comparative understandings of refugee policies in liberal democracies and their relation to constitutional and human rights. Street level bureaucracy, constitutional governance, federalism, integration, refugee resettlement policy, citizenship and belonging.  POLI_SCI 330-0 and LEGAL_ST 330-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Politics of the Supreme Court
courses.description: Operation of appellate courts, with emphasis on the US Supreme Court. Decision making by appellate courts and the development of public policy.

courses.name: Constitutional Law I
courses.description: Introduction to interpretation of the US Constitution by the Supreme Court. Judicial review, federalism, congressional and executive authority, separation of powers. Taught with LEGAL_ST 332-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Constitutional Law II: Civil and Political Rights
courses.description: Consideration of US Supreme Court decisions dealing with civil and political rights, including equality, freedom of speech, and freedom of religion. LEGAL_ST 333-0 and POLI_SCI 333-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Latino Politics
courses.description: Implications of Latino politics including contemporary social and political developments of Latino communities in the United States from a comparative urban framework. Focus on Mexican and Cuban Americans and Puerto Ricans.

courses.name: Political Psychology
courses.description: Examination of mental processes that underpin political judgments. Origins of political views, influence of parties and news media, decision-making heuristics and biases. Emphasis on ordinary citizens; some attention to elites.

courses.name: Immigration Politics and Policy
courses.description: Introduction to immigration politics in the U.S. with a focus on policies, public opinion, participation, and mobilization. Emphasis on relationships between nativity, citizenship status, legal status, and race/ethnicity.

courses.name: International Relations Theory
courses.description: Conceptual approaches to international relations, including "national interest," sovereignty, international norms and law, and rationality.

courses.name: International Political Economy
courses.description: Introduction to the politics of international economic relations. Roots and evolution of the international political economy. Fundamental controversies about international trade, finance, and development.

courses.name: International Organizations
courses.description: Institutions that govern the interactions of states, including the WTO, UN, ICJ, and ICC; informal norms, such as international intervention, international criminal law, and sovereignty. POLI_SCI 342-0 and LEGAL_ST 342-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Politics of International Law
courses.description: Non-utopian political science analysis of how law is used to promote collective goals and regulate international relations.

courses.name: U.S. Foreign Policy
courses.description: How US foreign policy is formulated, executed, legitimated, and contested. Topics include 9/11 and its aftermath, covert action, interventionism, trade, US respect for international norms, and US engagement with the Middle East.

courses.name: National Security
courses.description: Basic issues in national security, focusing primarily on the United States. Topics include the nature of "national interest," major actors in national security policy making and military strategy, and the influence and role of the defense establishment.

courses.name: European Union in International Affairs
courses.description: Introduction to the institutions and policies of the European Union today.

courses.name: Ethics in International Relations
courses.description: Role of ethical considerations in international relations: where and when ethical questions are raised and by whom; causes and predictability of tensions between the ethics and self-interests of nations and political figures.

courses.name: Globalization
courses.description: Analysis of changes in the world economy and their implications for politics, economics, and society. Politics of multinational production, finance, and trade in the context of governance problems in a globalizing world.

courses.name: International Environmental Politics
courses.description: International cooperation and conflict resolution of global and transnational environmental problems such as climate change. Role of political, economic, and normative considerations in the formation of politically feasible solutions to international environmental problems.

courses.name: Social Movements
courses.description: Theory and case studies examining the processes shaping collective challenges to authority. Topics include causes and mechanics of mobilization, the contexts in which movements emerge, repression and violence, strategies, and determinants of movement outcomes.

courses.name: Politics of the Middle East
courses.description: Survey of politics and political history of the Middle East and North Africa from World War I to the present. Topics include state building, authoritarianism, political economy, the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and the causes, trajectories, and aftermath of the 2011 Arab uprisings.

courses.name: Global Development
courses.description: Exploration of the economic and social changes constituting development, focusing on comparison between the historical experience in Europe and more recent processes in Africa, Asia, and Latin America. SOCIOL 317-0 and POLI_SCI 352-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Politics of Latin America
courses.description: Patterns of socioeconomic development and regime forms in Latin America. Interaction of internal and international economic and political structures and processes.

courses.name: Politics of Southeast Asia
courses.description: Political economy of selected Southeast Asian countries, 1945 to present. Important themes include oligarchy and human rights.

courses.name: Politics of China
courses.description: Chinese politics since 1949, focusing on social issues and state-society relations since 1989. Basic foundation for the non-specialist as well as preparation for advanced study.

courses.name: Constitutional Challenges in Comparative Perspective
courses.description: Constitutional controversies and resolutions in liberal democracies. Constitutional traditions and governance, rule of law, legitimacy and authority in diverse societies, human rights, social transformation. POLI_SCI 356-0 and LEGAL_ST 356-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Political Economy of Israel
courses.description: Influence of demographics, political factors, and Israeli-Palestinian conflict on development, economic policy, government spending, public health, and socio-economy. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Israel program.

courses.name: Contemporary South Africa: A Political Economy/Policy Perspective
courses.description: Analysis of the political outcomes of South Africa's transition to democracy, democratic consolidation, the state of the South African political economy, and major policy issues, such as gender equality and HIV/AIDS. Restricted to students in Northwestern's South Africa program.

courses.name: Politics of Africa
courses.description: Political structures and relation of cultural factors to political stability and change; development of modern political systems.

courses.name: Democratic Transitions
courses.description: Theories of the emergence and breakdown of democracy with a focus on cases from Europe, Latin America, Africa, and Asia.  Note: students cannot receive credit for both POLI_SCI 361-0 (Evanston) and POLI_SCI 361-SA (study abroad).

courses.name: Democratic Transitions
courses.description: Theories of the emergence and breakdown of democracy with a focus on cases from Europe, Latin America, Africa, and Asia.  Note: students cannot receive credit for both POLI_SCI 361-0 (Evanston) and POLI_SCI 361-SA (study abroad).

courses.name: Politics of Europe
courses.description: Impact of historical development on contemporary institutions, political and political-economic institutions, interest groups and parties, policy making, and social and economic policy.

courses.name: The Political Economy of the European Union
courses.description: The political production, structure, and regulation of economic activity in the EU. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: France: Politics, Culture, & Society
courses.description: Introduction to French politics in the framework of European integration. Covers French efforts to promote integration and France's role in the international system and adaptation to the EU. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: Decision Making in the European Union
courses.description: Analysis, by lecture and simulation, of the EU's complicated institutional structure for political decision making. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: The Dynamics of Law Making in the European Union
courses.description: Examination of the dynamics of law making in the EU and conflict/balance between domestic and regional law. Restricted to students in Northwestern's Paris program.

courses.name: Political Economy of Development
courses.description: Major analytical perspectives of modern political economy seen through concrete problems of development and underdevelopment in the least developed countries.

courses.name: Politics of Post-Soviet Russia
courses.description: Analysis of Russia's political and economic revolutions after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Examines key concepts in comparative politics, such as revolution, regime change, market formation, nationalism, and state building.

courses.name: The Middle East in International Politics
courses.description: International history and politics of the Arab states, Israel, Iran, and Turkey. Colonialism and nationalism, political Islam and secularism, the Iranian Revolution, the Gulf War of 1991, the US-led occupation of Iraq, relations between Turkey and the European Union. Recommended but not required: POLI_SCI 240-0.

courses.name: Chinese Foreign Policy
courses.description: Basic dynamics of Chinese foreign policy toward a variety of countries and regions.

courses.name: Politics of Capitalism
courses.description: Effects of politics on the economy and vice versa, especially in advanced industrial economies. The welfare state, varieties of capitalism, and neoliberalism.

courses.name: Civil Wars
courses.description: Focus on post-Cold War increase in civil wars, including causes and consequences of internal wars, and theories of conflict. Examines recent and contemporary civil wars to illustrate applications of theories and better understand current events.

courses.name: Drugs and Politics
courses.description: Analysis of the links between illegal drugs and politics, from the politics of local communities to international public policy. Regional focus on North, Central, and South America.

courses.name: America and the World
courses.description: Key debates and developments in the history and politics of American foreign relations. Domestic politics and foreign policy, political culture, interventionism, legal globalization, international institutions.

courses.name: China in Transition: Ideology, Political Economy, Law, and Relations with the US
courses.description: Broad issues confronting China in its long, tumultuous transition. For students with no background as well as those with extensive prior knowledge of China. Restricted to students in Northwestern's program in China.

courses.name: Refugee Crises and Human Rights
courses.description: Development of international human rights. Comparative state and regional responses to forced migration due to war, conflict, and generalized violence. Humanitarian intervention, international law, and policy issues, such as gender-based violence, migrants at sea, and human trafficking. POLI_SCI 380-0 and LEGAL_ST 380-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Political Economy of Contemporary China
courses.description: State capitalism, the role of state-owned enterprises in China's economic development, China as a regulatory state, social consequences, financial reforms. Restricted to students in Northwestern's program in China.

courses.name: Politics of Religious Diversity
courses.description: Intersection of religion, law, and politics in comparative and global perspective. Legal, political, and religious history; discrimination and identity; religion, race, indigeneity, empire; religious liberalization; rule of law; national security.

courses.name: War and Change in International Politics
courses.description: Historical and contemporary forms of international order. Western and non-Eurocentric systems; how international order emerges; whether the post-1945 order will change.

courses.name: International Responses to Mass Atrocities
courses.description: How the international community can respond to mass atrocities and human rights violations.

courses.name: Institutions and Society
courses.description: Institutions in a broad societal context. How institutional frameworks apply to government, family, education, and the environment; implications of institutions. POLI_SCI 388-0 and SOCIOL 288-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Understanding Genocide
courses.description: Key debates in the comparative study of genocide. Why genocide occurs, why people become killers, how these processes relate to each other.  POLI_SCI 389-0 and SOCIOL 379-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Special Topics in Political Science
courses.description: Designed for investigation of topics of interest to students and faculty that are not covered by other course offerings. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Special Topics in Political Science
courses.description: Designed for investigation of topics of interest to students and faculty that are not covered by other course offerings. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Political Research Seminar
courses.description: Required of all political science majors; ordinarily taken during junior or senior year.

courses.name: Senior Thesis Seminar
courses.description: Two consecutive quarters (fall and winter) during which students work on their senior theses.

courses.name: Senior Thesis Seminar
courses.description: Two consecutive quarters (fall and winter) during which students work on their senior theses.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Study and research projects carried out under faculty supervision. A written proposal, signed by the professor with whom the student will study, should be submitted to the director of undergraduate studies. Consent of department required.

courses.name: Elementary Portuguese
courses.description: Introduction to grammar and development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Brazilian Portuguese, as well as the history and culture of Portuguese-speaking countries.

courses.name: Elementary Portuguese
courses.description: Introduction to grammar and development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Brazilian Portuguese, as well as the history and culture of Portuguese-speaking countries.

courses.name: Elementary Portuguese
courses.description: Introduction to grammar and development of listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Brazilian Portuguese, as well as the history and culture of Portuguese-speaking countries.

courses.name: First-Year Seminar
courses.description: WCAS first-year seminar.

courses.name: Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
courses.description: For students proficient in Spanish. Comparative sociolinguistic and interactive approach to communicative competence emphasizing pronunciation, intonation, sentence structure, and patterns of spoken and written Portuguese.

courses.name: Portuguese for Spanish Speakers
courses.description: For students proficient in Spanish. Comparative sociolinguistic and interactive approach to communicative competence emphasizing pronunciation, intonation, sentence structure, and patterns of spoken and written Portuguese.

courses.name: Intermediate Portuguese
courses.description: Port 121 helps students achieve an intermediate level of proficiency through further development of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills. Grammar, vocabulary and pronunciation of Brazilian Portuguese will continue to be developed through meaningful cultural contexts. The course also offers insights into the history and culture of the Portuguese speaking countries in Europe, Africa and America.

courses.name: Intermediate Portuguese
courses.description: Port 121 helps students achieve an intermediate level of proficiency through further development of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills. Grammar, vocabulary and pronunciation of Brazilian Portuguese will continue to be developed through meaningful cultural contexts. The course also offers insights into the history and culture of the Portuguese speaking countries in Europe, Africa and America.

courses.name: Intermediate Portuguese
courses.description: Port 121 helps students achieve an intermediate level of proficiency through further development of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills. Grammar, vocabulary and pronunciation of Brazilian Portuguese will continue to be developed through meaningful cultural contexts. The course also offers insights into the history and culture of the Portuguese speaking countries in Europe, Africa and America.

courses.name: Reading and Speaking Portuguese
courses.description: This intermediate course is designed to expand mastery in reading and speaking Brazilian Portuguese through select cultural videos, readings of literary cronicas, periodicals, and the Internet.

courses.name: Reading and Writing Portuguese
courses.description: Instruction in reading and writing expository and narrative prose. Emphasis on vocabulary, linguistic skills, and syntax appropriate to formal written Portuguese.

courses.name: Icons, Legends, and Myths in Brazil
courses.description: Representations in graphic materials, documentaries, film, theater, folklore, narrative fiction, and popular music of historical, literary, and popular figures in the national imagination. May include English or Portuguese discussion sections. Prerequisite for Portuguese section: PORT 201-0, PORT 202-0, or sufficient score on placement exam. Prerequisite for English section: none.

courses.name: Topics in Advanced Portuguese
courses.description: Advanced review of grammar concepts and idiomatic use of spoken and written Portuguese. Deals with a variety of topics in the context of Brazilian culture, history, literature, and current events. May be taken more than once for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Contemporary Brazil: Literature and Film
courses.description: Study of the literature and film produced in Brazil during the 21st century. Focus on narrative forms, genres, and sociocultural issues.

courses.name: Topics in Lusophone Cultures
courses.description: Aspects of the literatures and cultures of Brazil, Portugal, and Lusophone Africa (Mozambique, Angola, Cape Verde, São Tomé and Principe, Guinea-Bissau). Possible topics include Brazilian modernism, Lusophone African literature and film, race and sexuality in Brazilian literature, travel narrative, literature and ethnography, the Portuguese novel, nation and nationalism. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Independent study under supervision. Consultation with the director of undergraduate studies required.

courses.name: Introduction to Psychology
courses.description: A survey course reviewing primary psychological research and theories of human behavior. Laboratory experience exposes students to psychology as a research science.

courses.name: Statistical Methods in Psychology
courses.description: Measurement; descriptive statistics; probability and sampling; T-test, ANOVA, correlation, and regression.

courses.name: Research Methods in Psychology
courses.description: Methods of psychological research; experimental design; reliability and validity; review and application of statistics; execution and reporting of psychological research.

courses.name: Social Psychology
courses.description: Psychological processes underlying social behavior; topics include social cognition, attraction, aggression, prejudice, and behavior in groups.

courses.name: Psychology of Personality
courses.description: Nature of personality and its development. Modern theoretical interpretations. Biological and social bases of individual differences.

courses.name: Introduction to Neuroscience
courses.description: Designed for students with no prior coursework in neuroscience or biology. Neurophysiology and neuroanatomy; neuroscience of perception, emotion, morality, memory, mental illness, and consciousness. Neuroscience majors may not take PSYCH 221-0.  Students may not take PSYCH 221-0 after they have taken NEUROSCI 202-0.

courses.name: Cognitive Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to research into mental processes such as memory, reasoning, problem solving, and decision making.

courses.name: Developmental Psychology
courses.description: Development of cognitive, social, and other psychological functions.

courses.name: Presenting Ideas & Data
courses.description: Understanding principles of cognitive psychology, data visualization, and graphic design to present ideas and data in an engaging, clear, and memorable manner. PSYCH 245-0 and COG_SCI 245-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Health Psychology
courses.description: Overview of research in health psychology. Stress and coping, biological systems affected by stress, social support and health, health behaviors, adjustment to chronic illnesses.

courses.name: Buddhist Psychology
courses.description: Buddhist and scientific psychological views of mind and behavior; meditation techniques.

courses.name: Psychopathology
courses.description: Understanding the nature of psychological, emotional, and behavioral disorders. Emphasis on current evidence regarding causes and characteristics of these disorders.

courses.name: Introduction to Clinical Psychology
courses.description: Definition and history of clinical psychology, personality theory in clinical psychology, diagnosis and classification of disorders, assessment, psychotherapy, and ethical issues.

courses.name: Cognitive Behavior Therapy
courses.description: Scientific foundations of cognitive behavior therapy for a wide range of disorders. Focus on the rationale for different treatments and evidence of efficacy and process. Comparisons with other scientifically validated treatments.

courses.name: Special Topics in Social/Clinical/Personality
courses.description: Topic to be announced. Prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Psychology of Attitudes
courses.description: Survey of social psychological research on attitudes; focus on the formation of attitudes, the relationship between attitudes and behavior, and attitude change.

courses.name: Relationship Science
courses.description: Social-psychological analysis of close relationships, with an emphasis on romantic relationships. Interpersonal processes associated with relationship formation, development, and dissolution.

courses.name: The Holocaust: Psychological Themes & Perspectives
courses.description: This course will be an exploration of how particular psychological theories and concepts can inform our understanding of the events of the Holocaust at both a group and individual level. Material from the fields of Social and Clinical Psychology will be a particular focus of the course.

courses.name: Intermediate Neuroscience
courses.description: Intermediate principles of neuroscience; neurophysiology, neuropharmacology, neuroanatomy, and electrophysiological substrates of psychological processes.

courses.name: Perception
courses.description: Human perception, particularly vision but also hearing, taste, smell, and touch. Biological foundations, development, and disorders of perception. The senses in everyday life.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Neuroscience and Psychophysiology
courses.description: Applied psychophysiology; brain activity coding of cognitive events, biofeedback, opiate pain control.

courses.name: Brain and Cognition
courses.description: Neural bases of cognitive processing with emphases on neuroimaging approaches in the areas of encoding, perception, attention, memory, language, reading, motor control, and executive functioning.  Taught with CSD 303-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Brain Damage and the Mind
courses.description: Survey of human cognition as studied via investigations of brain damage and brain-imaging techniques.

courses.name: Special Topics in Cognition/Neuroscience
courses.description: Topic to be announced. Prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Psychology of Thinking
courses.description: Research methods and recent experimental findings for types of human thinking. Students conduct original research.

courses.name: Consciousness
courses.description: Examines how psychologists, neuroscientists, computer scientists, and physicists have tackled fundamental questions about consciousness using empirical and theoretical methods.

courses.name: Psychology and Law
courses.description: Examines the application of psychology to law, including topics such as the insanity defense, criminal profiling, eyewitness testimony, and interrogation.

courses.name: Positive Psychology: The Science of Well-Being
courses.description: Key developments in the field of positive psychology. Eudaimonic and hedonic wellbeing, mindfulness and flow, importance of social connections, emotional resilience, positive institutions.

courses.name: Evolutionary Psychology
courses.description: Theory, methodology, and empirical data related to how evolution has influenced human psychology and behavior. Emphasis on mating.

courses.name: Psychology of Beauty
courses.description: Theory, methodology, and empirical data related to the psychological impact of human beauty. Emphasis on both cultural and evolutionary perspectives.

courses.name: Cultural Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to concepts and empirical methods used to study how culture shapes mind, brain, and behavior over multiple time scales, including over generations and the lifespan and across situational contexts.

courses.name: Psychology of Gender
courses.description: Examination of sex differences and similarities. Evaluation of explanations for differences. Review of how gender affects achievement, relationships, and mental health.

courses.name: Special Topics in Psychology
courses.description: Topic to be announced. Prerequisites vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Native Americans and Environmental Decision Making
courses.description: Focus on Native Americans, culture and cultural processes, and environmental decision making. Emphasis on contemporary Native American cultures and relevant research. ENVR_POL 356-0 and PSYCH 356-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Personality Research
courses.description: Research in personality, with emphasis on experimental approaches and methods. Basic concepts of test reliability and validity. Students conduct original research.

courses.name: Social and Personality Development
courses.description: Research methods, theories, and facts relating to the development and modification of attitudes and behavior.

courses.name: Stereotyping & Prejudice
courses.description: Analysis of the causes and consequences of stereotyping and prejudice, as well as methods used to study these issues. Students conduct original research.

courses.name: Child Psychopathology
courses.description: Major forms of psychopathology present during childhood, including disorders exclusive to childhood and those that may appear during any developmental period. Developmental models of the etiology and course of major psychopathologies.

courses.name: Psychological Tests & Measures
courses.description: Explores the science of psychological assessment, including its history, test construction and evaluation, and common measures of personality, psychopathology, and ability. Students create and evaluate their own psychological measures.

courses.name: Cognitive Development
courses.description: Cognitive development in infancy, childhood, and adolescence. Focus on theoretical explanations for cognitive change and development in core domains, including language, space, number, time, and social relations.

courses.name: Language and Cognition
courses.description: Exposure to original research and theoretical perspectives on language and its relation to thought and behavior. Critical analysis of theories and methods. Topics may vary.

courses.name: Decision Making
courses.description: Human decision making from both descriptive and prescriptive perspectives. Theories and models of decision making applied to a variety of contexts.

courses.name: Human Memory
courses.description: Scientific study of human memory, including memory systems of the brain, amnesia, remembering, forgetting, encoding, consolidation, memory suppression, and memory distortion. Emphasizes original research reports in cognitive neuroscience.

courses.name: Images of Cognition
courses.description: Study of brain processes underlying cognition. Analysis of brain structure and function. Introduction to imaging techniques including fMRI, PET, and ERP.

courses.name: Neuroscience & Behavior Laboratory
courses.description: Classical exercises in the physiological psychology laboratory, including brainwave recording and electrophysiology.

courses.name: Advanced Statistics & Experimental Design
courses.description: Advanced topics in research design and analysis of data. Focus on both theory and applications.

courses.name: Children & the Law
courses.description: Examines from a developmental perspective research on children's involvement in the legal system as decision makers, witnesses, victims, and perpetrators. Taught with LEGAL_ST 381-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Psychology and Food
courses.description: Social, cultural, cognitive, evolutionary, and biological factors that influence food choice and consumption. Conducting and evaluating research on eating behavior. Students conduct original research.

courses.name: Consumer Psychology and Marketing Research
courses.description: Application of psychological theories, findings, and methodologies to marketing research questions and problems. Students conduct a marketing research project for an actual client.

courses.name: Advanced Seminar in Personality, Clinical, or Social Psychology
courses.description: Discussion and critical analysis of research methods and findings in an area of personality, clinical, and/or social psychology. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Advanced Seminar in Cognition or Neuroscience
courses.description: Discussion and critical analysis of research methods and findings in an area of cognitive psychology and/or neuroscience. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Advanced Seminar in Psychology
courses.description: Discussion and critical analysis of research methods and findings in psychology. Interdisciplinary focus, often spanning natural and social science aspects of psychology. Topics vary. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Advanced Supervised Research 1
courses.description: Design, implementation, and reporting of a psychology research project.

courses.name: Advanced Supervised Research 2
courses.description: Design, implementation, and reporting of a psychology research project.

courses.name: Senior Thesis Seminar
courses.description: Open only to students pursuing departmental honors. They must apply for admission in spring quarter of junior year.

courses.name: Senior Thesis Seminar
courses.description: Open only to students pursuing departmental honors. They must apply for admission in spring quarter of junior year.

courses.name: Senior Thesis Seminar
courses.description: Open only to students pursuing departmental honors. They must apply for admission in spring quarter of junior year.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Consent of instructor required. Generally limited to juniors and seniors.  See department requirements for eligibility.

courses.name: Media Construction
courses.description: Introduces the core components of media-idea, image, sound, and sequence- with the technical fundamentals involved in shooting and editing video. Students work with SLR and digital video cameras and with Photoshop and Final Cut Pro editing software, completing four projects in different genres during the quarter. Prerequisite for all upper-level production courses. Required for majors; typically taken in first year.

courses.name: First-Year Topics Seminar
courses.description: Beginning seminar focused around a special topic of media analysis, history, or theory. Students will learn research, analytic, and writing skills while focusing on issues relevant to film, media and/or digital arts and culture.

courses.name: Analyzing Media Texts
courses.description: Introduction to the study of the moving image. Basic elements of style across media including film, television, and interactive media. Focus on close analysis of texts to find significance. Prerequisite for upper level courses in the department. Required for majors; typically taken in first year.

courses.name: Foundations of Screenwriting
courses.description: Introduction to writing for the screen (film, television, and/or computer). Structure, character, dialogue, format, voice, scope, pace, context. Lecture/workshop. Prerequisite for upper-level writing courses in the department.

courses.name: Studies in Media Topics
courses.description: Theoretical or practical or both; emphasis on evolving trends.

courses.name: Television History
courses.description: Political, cultural, social, and industrial history of television, from the classic network era to the post-network contemporary period of media convergence. Exploration of programs as well as major events and shifts in television history.

courses.name: History of Film I
courses.description: International survey of motion pictures as a distinctive medium of expression from its prehistory to the present.

courses.name: History of Film II
courses.description: International survey of motion pictures as a distinctive medium of expression from its prehistory to the present.

courses.name: Doc Film History & Criticism
courses.description: Survey of the schools, styles, and purposes of documentary film as a unique form of artistic expression and sociopolitical persuasion.

courses.name: Documentary Film & Video
courses.description: Contemporary work and issues in documentary film and video.

courses.name: History of the Recording Industry
courses.description: Exploration of the history of the recording industry from the invention of the phonograph in 1877 to recent developments in digital audio.

courses.name: Audio Drama
courses.description: Introduction to masterpieces of audio and radio drama in three historical periods: classic American (1937-54); mid-century British (1954-1974) and contemporary global traditions.

courses.name: Media and Cultural Theory
courses.description: Introduction to the critical analysis of film, television, and other popular media by surveying influential theories of media, culture, and power.

courses.name: Radio/Tv/Film Authorship
courses.description: Idea of authorship in the media and an examination of different uses of author theory related to the work of particular artists.

courses.name: Radio/Television/Film Genre
courses.description: Concept of genre in the media, with reference to popular American forms.

courses.name: Film, Media & Gender
courses.description: Explores issues of gender in film and media. Introduces students to major debates and theories regarding gender and sexuality in the media.

courses.name: Film & TV Criticism
courses.description: Contemporary critical methods applied to film and/or television. Students read literature on critical methods and analysis and write critical analyses of films and television programs.

courses.name: Culture Industries
courses.description: Overview of business and social organization of film and television industry. Introduction to how media industries produce cultural products for local, national, and transnational audiences.

courses.name: Technological Innovations
courses.description: How technology develops and is assimilated into mass media.

courses.name: History of Hollywood Cinema
courses.description: Overview of the development of the classical Hollywood cinema, with particular emphasis on the 1920s through the early 1960s. Explores the relationship between industry practices and aesthetic features of classical narrative film genres.

courses.name: National Cinema
courses.description: Historical aspects of cinema in a culture outside the United States or a social/cultural/intellectual movement within cinema's general evolution.

courses.name: Film, Media, and Globalization
courses.description: Explores theories of media's role in the globalization of cultures. Examines transnational production, marketing, and reception of film, television, and/or digital media.

courses.name: Topics in Improv
courses.description: In-depth study and practice of improv techniques and aesthetics.  Sample topics include Intro to Improv, Improvising Characters, Writing and Performing Stand-up, Writing with Improv, Improvising the Text-based Collaborative Show, Improvised Comedy Web Series.

courses.name: Topics in Media Writing
courses.description: Various approaches to screenwriting, emphasizing different modes and genres, such as the short film, the feature film, screenplays based on preexisting material, the teen film, interactive computer scenarios. May be repeated for credit, depending on the change in topic.

courses.name: Writing the TV Pilot
courses.description: Students will learn the craft of writing a television pilot in this small, workshop-based course.

courses.name: Writing the Feature
courses.description: Students will learn the craft of writing a feature film in this small, workshop-based course.

courses.name: Writing the Adaptation
courses.description: Students will learn the craft of writing an adaptation in this small, workshop-based course.

courses.name: Introduction to Acting for the Screen
courses.description: Foundational concerns and practices for screen acting. Scene analysis, rehearsal, staging and camera space, casting, editing for performance. Creating and portraying characters for most effective capture by the camera. Film directing techniques as related to the actor. Required introductory course for the Acting for Screen module sequence.

courses.name: Diagnostic Scene Study
courses.description: Retrospective critique of curricular and extracurricular performance work in the Acting for Screen module. Evaluation of performer's range and capabilities in terms of future projects and identity as an actor. Relationship between actor and director relative to the camera. Required course for the module.

courses.name: Topics in Acting for the Screen
courses.description: Production-based courses on a range of practices and methods in acting for screen. May be repeated as topic varies. Counts as elective for the Acting for Screen module.

courses.name: Topics in Pre-Production
courses.description: In-depth study of preproduction film, video, and media techniques and aesthetics. Sample topics include storyboarding, producing, and motion graphics.

courses.name: Editing
courses.description: The technique and art of editing for film. Topics include editing for continuity, controlling pace and rhythm, and editing nonlinear narratives.

courses.name: Topics in Sound
courses.description: In-depth study of sound techniques and aesthetics.

courses.name: Topics in Cinematography
courses.description: In-depth study of cinematography techniques and aesthetics.

courses.name: Topics in Interactive Media
courses.description: Exploration of the techniques and aesthetics of interactivity using various media.

courses.name: Topics in Non-fiction Media
courses.description: In-depth study of nonfiction media techniques and aesthetics.

courses.name: Topics in Post-Production
courses.description: In-depth study of postproduction film, video, and media techniques and aesthetics. Sample topics include color correction, special-effects cinematography, and finishing.

courses.name: Topics in Film/Video/Audio Production
courses.description: In-depth study and practice of one area of film, video, or television. May be taken more than once for credit, depending on changes in topic.

courses.name: Lighting and Cinematography
courses.description: Techniques, aesthetics, and technologies of lighting and camera skills, including film and video.

courses.name: Introduction to Sound Production
courses.description: Introduction to the theories and principles of basic sound production. Demos, lectures, readings, screenings, and exercises cover all basics of sound recording technology.

courses.name: Introduction to Sound Postproduction
courses.description: Introduction to the theories and principles of basic sound production. Demos, lectures, readings, screenings, and exercises cover all basics of sound recording technology.

courses.name: Practicum in RTVF Research
courses.description: Collaboration with a faculty member on design and execution of a media research project. Students learn how to construct and complete a research project and document results. Requires a paper or other form of work product as determined by the faculty member.

courses.name: Directing
courses.description: Single-camera dramatic directing, including visualization and breakdown of scripts, camera blocking, and working with actors.

courses.name: Documentary Production
courses.description: Students examine documentary practices and produce their own shorts.

courses.name: 2D Computer Animation
courses.description: Animation techniques in the 2-D sphere and incorporation of visual design principles.

courses.name: Experimental Media Production
courses.description: Creation of an experimental work as a linear film or video, an interactive website, an installation, a game, or a multidisciplinary performance.

courses.name: Computer Animation: 3D
courses.description: The fundamental concepts and techniques of 3-D computer modeling and animation. Use of concepts acquired in camera-based production techniques to create a rendered animation.

courses.name: Advanced Directing I
courses.description: Two-quarter sequence for students creating advanced artistic production, with critique of work throughout the production and postproduction process; conceptual resources offered as needed. Students may work in any genre (documentary, narrative, experimental) and any medium. Admission based on portfolio of previous media work and proposal for project, including script and budget.

courses.name: Advanced Directing II
courses.description: Two-quarter sequence for students creating advanced artistic production, with critique of work throughout the production and postproduction process; conceptual resources offered as needed. Students may work in any genre (documentary, narrative, experimental) and any medium. Admission based on portfolio of previous media work and proposal for project, including script and budget.

courses.name: Symposium: Issues in RTVF
courses.description: Special issues and topics in the analysis of radio, television, film, and popular culture.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Prerequisite: consent of undergraduate dean after submission of petition.

courses.name: Introduction to Religion
courses.description: Religion as it has appeared in the past and as humans continue to express it in their personal and social lives.

courses.name: Introduction to Religion, Media, and Culture
courses.description: Integrating multimedia modes of learning and engaging students in skill-developing mediamaking assignments, this course offers undergraduates an introduction to studying the phenomena of religion in relationship to dynamics of media, society, and culture. No prerequisites required.

courses.name: Religion, Medicine & Suffering in the West
courses.description: Examination of religious healing ceremonies and Christian perspectives on pain and suffering in light of the meaning of physical pain in people's everyday lives.

courses.name: Introduction to Hinduism
courses.description: Unity and diversity of Hindu mythology, beliefs, and practices from ancient times to the present.

courses.name: Introduction to Buddhism
courses.description: The Buddha's life and teachings, traditions that developed from these teachings, and systems of meditation, rituals, and ethics.

courses.name: Introduction to Hebrew Bible
courses.description: Major genres of Old Testament literature. Basic theological views and the sociopolitical history of ancient Israel.

courses.name: Introduction to the New Testament
courses.description: Beginning, development, and content of the New Testament; its Jewish and Hellenistic environment.

courses.name: Introduction to Judaism
courses.description: Main concepts in the theology of Judaism, main rituals and customs, and main institutions.

courses.name: Introduction to Christianity
courses.description: Doctrine, worship, and institutions in the various branches of Christianity.

courses.name: Introduction to Islam
courses.description: Principal beliefs and practices of Muslims set against the historic development of the faith.

courses.name: Introduction to Native American Religions
courses.description: Diversity and common elements of Native American religious traditions; comparative study of sacred story, ritual, spiritual philosophy, and practice.

courses.name: American Religion, Ecology and Culture
courses.description: The historical rise of environmentalism in American culture and its impact on religious thought and practice. ENVR_POL 261-0 and RELIGION 261-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: American Religious History from 1865 to the Great Depression
courses.description: Topics include urban religion, African American churches, Christians and foreign policy, immigrant religion, the spiritual crisis of the 1920s, and Pentecostalism.

courses.name: American Religious History from World War II to the Present
courses.description: Religion and the making of contemporary America, including Cold War religion, the Black Gods of the Great Migration, the rise of the Christian Right, and modern American Catholicism and Judaism.

courses.name: Introduction to Theology
courses.description: Theology as an academic discipline with a long history of asking-in dialogue with thinkers past and present-fundamental questions about religious experience, texts, practices, and ideas.

courses.name: Theology of Love
courses.description: The concept of love from theological, historical, philosophical, and biblical perspectives.

courses.name: Luther and the West
courses.description: Examination of Luther's work in the context of his life and times. Introduces basic dimensions of Western thought, showing how theology relates to broader cultural, political, social, and aesthetic issues. GERMAN 272-0 and RELIGION 272-0 are taught together; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Mysticism and Spirituality
courses.description: Examines mysticism (mystical experience, relationship, prayer, or consciousness) and spirituality (spiritual presence and practice) across religious traditions and outside traditions.

courses.name: Ahimsa: Nonviolence in South Asia and Beyond
courses.description: Theory and practice of nonviolence in human action, taking into account ethics as well as efficacy. Emphasis on both spiritual and practical approaches to nonviolence and its usefulness in effecting spiritual development and social change.

courses.name: Hindu Epics: Mahābhārata
courses.description: Immersion in the ancient Sanskrit epic in translation and modern retellings, focusing on classical Hindu myth and theology as well as issues of justice, war, gender, and violence.

courses.name: Hindu Epics: Rāmāyaṇa
courses.description: Immersion in the ancient Sanskrit epic in translation and modern retellings, focusing on classical Hindu myth and theology as well as issues of justice, violence, gender, and love.

courses.name: Topics in Hinduism
courses.description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Buddhism and Gender
courses.description: Women, men, and gendered symbolism in Buddhism from the time of the Buddha to the present. Draws on canonical texts, narrative literature, autobiography and biography, and ethnography.

courses.name: Tibetan Religion and Culture
courses.description: Propagation of religions in Tibet in their larger historical, cultural, and political contexts.

courses.name: Buddhism in the Contemporary World
courses.description: An exploration of where, why, and how Buddhist practices, ideas, and iconography are spreading and being reinterpreted in the modern world.

courses.name: Buddhist Auto/biography
courses.description: An exploration of Buddhist narratives of the self, including Sanskrit and Tibetan-language biographies and autobiographies in English translation, in conversation with literary theory.

courses.name: Religion and the Body in China
courses.description: Explores the place of the body in Chinese religion, from the ancient period to the present day. Touches on dying and the afterlife, food and drink, health and medicine, gender and family, and other themes.

courses.name: Topics in East Asian Religions
courses.description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Topics in Buddhism
courses.description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Topics in the Bible
courses.description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Varieties of Ancient Judaism
courses.description: Introduction to the Judaisms that flourished from the fifth century BCE to the third century CE.

courses.name: Modern Jewish Thought
courses.description: How Judaism dealt with modernity and the problems it posed: Spinoza, Mendelssohn, Cohen, Buber, Rosenzweig, and Levinas.

courses.name: Judaism in the Modern World
courses.description: Radical changes that emancipation and modernity have brought to the religious expression of Judaism. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Topics in Judaism
courses.description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Christian Mystical Theology
courses.description: Writings of mystics  (e.g., Meister Eckhart, Cloud of Unknowing, Julian of Norwich, Teresa of Avila) in their cultural context.

courses.name: Blood, Sex, and Justice: Issues in Christian Ethics
courses.description: Four contemporary moral issues viewed from a variety of Christian approaches.

courses.name: Idea of Sainthood in Christianity
courses.description: Historical and contemporary conceptions of sanctity, especially in Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy.

courses.name: Church Architecture
courses.description: Survey of historical and recent churches: spatial dynamics, centering focus, aesthetic impact, and symbolic resonance.

courses.name: Topics in Christianity
courses.description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: The Qur'an
courses.description: Islam's sacred scripture, Muslim understandings of revelation and prophecy, and debates about the Qur'an in the contemporary world.

courses.name: Islamic Law
courses.description: Evolution of Islamic Law from the Prophet Muhammad to the contemporary world, focusing on the impact of colonialism.

courses.name: Trends in Islamic Thought
courses.description: Qur'anic, medieval, and modern approaches to problems in faith and social action.

courses.name: Sufism
courses.description: The historical development of Islamic mystical traditions, with special attention to notions of mystical experience, sainthood, and devotion to the Prophet Muhammad.

courses.name: Topics in Islam
courses.description: Selected topics in Islamic history and thought. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: Topics in Islam
courses.description: Selected topics in Islamic history and thought. May be repeated for credit with different topic.

courses.name: African American Religions
courses.description: Exploration of the historical diversity of African American religious experiences and identities.

courses.name: Topics in Women and Religion in America
courses.description: Topics, figures, events, and dynamics in the history of American women and religion.

courses.name: American Teenage Rites of Passage
courses.description: Examination of various rites of passage experienced by US teens.

courses.name: Topics in American Religion
courses.description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Religion and Film
courses.description: Content varies (e.g., films of Robert Bresson; Kieslowski's Decalogue; Dreyer and Tarkovsky). May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Religion and Bioethics
courses.description: Analysis of contemporary dilemmas in medicine and the life sciences; responses to these dilemmas from religious perspectives.

courses.name: Contemporary Religious Thought
courses.description: Content varies (e.g., convergence between religious paths, science and religion, politics and religion). May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Foundations of Christian Thought
courses.description: Christian interpretations of salvation, Christ, and God, from Augustine to Julian of Norwich.

courses.name: Christianity and the Making of Modernity
courses.description: Role of Christian thought in shaping the turbulent history of the West from the 16th to the late-18th centuries. Christianity's engagement with local and global events, from reformation to revolution, reason to romanticism.

courses.name: Christian Thought in Global Perspective
courses.description: Globalization of Christian thought in the 19th-21st centuries, considering religious differences, colonialism, war, and democracy. Approaches to theology in Asia, Latin America, and Africa.

courses.name: Death: Myth and Meaning
courses.description: Ideas, beliefs, and practices pertaining to death from a variety of ancient and modern cultures. Immortality, afterlife, care for the dying, suicide, funerary rituals, transhumanism.

courses.name: Topics in Comparative Religion
courses.description: Content varies. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Global Catholicism in the Contemporary World
courses.description: Historical and contemporary global Catholicism. Topics include the church and political modernity; local saints; controversies over worship styles; Catholics and political revolutions; the Vatican; the pontificate of John Paul II.

courses.name: Catholicism & Making of the Modern World
courses.description: 16th-17th century Catholic influences on missions, colonial ventures, science, and the development of non-European history; the effects of these efforts upon Catholicism's understanding of itself and early "global culture."

courses.name: Catholic Social Ethics
courses.description: Ecclesiastical, academic, and popular Catholic social ethics from 1891 to the present-for example, the living wage and Catholic Worker movements, peace initiatives, liberation ethics, and immigration, environment, sexuality, and gender issues.

courses.name: Soundings in the Catholic Tradition
courses.description: Topics in Catholic religious thought or religious movements. May be taken multiple times with different content.

courses.name: Topics in United States Catholicism
courses.description: Historical and contemporary subjects in the study of Catholic culture in the United States. May be taken multiple times with different content.

courses.name: Topics in Latin America Catholicism
courses.description: Historical and contemporary subjects in the study of Catholic culture in Latin America. May be taken multiple times with different content.

courses.name: Theories of Religion
courses.description: Ways of critically analyzing religious experience and its meaning. Phenomenology of religion, history of religions, comparative religions. For majors only.

courses.description: For honors students writing the senior thesis.

courses.name: Senior Seminar
courses.description: For honors students writing the senior thesis.

courses.description: Reading and conferences on special subjects for advanced students. Consent of instructor required.

courses.description: Russian language and culture. Basic reading, writing, listening, and speaking. No prerequisite.

courses.description: Russian for advanced speakers, including heritage speakers. Stress on skills in speaking, reading, and writing in professional and formal environments. Taught entirely in Russian.

courses.units: Prior to 2019 taught as SLAVIC 359-1 or 359-2)
courses.description: Selected works of Russian masters. Lecture, readings and discussion in Russian. Russian modernist prose, socialist realism and 1940s to the present. Content varies. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Community Engagement
courses.description: Critical reflection on community service experiences in relation to broader societal issues. Conceptual frameworks for understanding the meaning and nature of community. For Civic Engagement Certificate students only.

courses.name: Understanding Knowledge
courses.description: N/A.

courses.name: Human Development: Childhood and Adolescence
courses.description: Personal, social, and cognitive development from birth through adolescence. Interplay of biological and experiential factors on linguistic and conceptual development, ego, and personality.

courses.name: Introduction to Community Development
courses.description: Historical and contemporary community-building efforts, focusing on Chicago's neighborhoods. Community development strategies: the settlement house, community organizing, and community economic development.

courses.name: Human Development: Adulthood and Aging
courses.description: Psychological, sociological, and biological factors influencing socialization and development from young and middle adulthood through old age. Influences of family, school, and work on the individual.

courses.name: Designing for Social Change
courses.description: Processes, challenges, and ethics of designing programs, at home and abroad, for realizing human rights and meaningful social change.

courses.name: Introduction to Statistics and Research Methodology
courses.description: Definitions and classifications of terms used in quantitative methods; measures of typical and maximum performance, reliability, and validity checks; reporting and displaying data; interpreting results.

courses.name: Leaders Lab

courses.name: Field Research Methods
courses.description: Guided practice in systematic and participant observation. Observer bias, field notes, unobtrusive measures.

courses.name: Peer-Led Learning: Theory and Practice
courses.description: SESP 291 is the training program for students working as first-time mentors in the Peer Leaders program. It is taken over two academic quarters, with each quarter offering .25 credit (a total of .5 credit). You will receive a "K" grade for fall quarter, which means you are continuing in the course. After winter quarter, you will receive a letter grade which will be retroactively applied to fall quarter.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Community Consulting
courses.description: Course on the importance of community capacity building and the community-consulting process; start of preliminary work for the Certificate in Civic Engagement capstone project.

courses.name: Student Organized Seminar
courses.description: Courses proposed by students and supervised by faculty sponsors on special topics approved by the SESP undergraduate education director. May be taken only once per quarter; pass/no credit only. Consultation with the SESP student affairs assistant dean advised.

courses.name: Gender and the Life Course
courses.description: How gender influences major life stages. Focus on the psychosocial effects of gender on children; young, midlife, and old adults; societal institutions; and selected social policy issues.

courses.name: Race and Education
courses.description: Conceptual underpinnings of the construct of race and how conceptions of race have influenced the course of education in the United States.

courses.name: Crafting Child Policy
courses.description: N/A.

courses.name: Pedagogies for History and Injustice: Holocaust Education Design

courses.name: Race, Adolescence, and School Discipline
courses.description: In recent years, racial disparities in school discipline have attracted the attention of educators, policymakers, parents, and the general public. Why is it so hard for legal, political, and educational institutions to improve school discipline? How do intersections of race, gender, and social class matter for students' experiences of school discipline? Are there schools that are getting discipline right? What does that look like, and to what extent can other schools learn from their successes? In this course, we will learn about evidence-based policy improvements and imagine how to create schools where race does not predict discipline.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.description: Advanced work on special topics.

courses.name: Special Topics
courses.description: Advanced work on special topics. This course is limited to students approved to study abroad through the Global Learning Office (GLO).

courses.name: Practicum in Human Development; Learning Sciences
courses.description: Real-world participant observation in professional activities and projects; development of analytical field studies of the practicum experience based on field notes, recorded observations, and class discussions; culminates in a final research paper.

courses.description: See description for SESP 382-0. Offered during Summer Session only.

courses.description: Opportunity to participate in faculty research projects.

courses.description: Overview of research methods that may be used to design and implement the honors thesis.

courses.name: Senior Thesis Seminar
courses.description: Students develop, design, implement, and evaluate a research project under a faculty advisor's guidance.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Faculty-supervised study of special topics of the student's own choosing and not covered in regular courses.

courses.name: Science in Human Culture Senior Seminar
courses.description: For students who wish to qualify for honors by writing a senior thesis.

courses.name: Science in Human Culture Senior Seminar
courses.description: For students who wish to qualify for honors by writing a senior thesis.

courses.name: Science in Human Culture Senior Seminar
courses.description: For students who wish to qualify for honors by writing a senior thesis.

courses.name: Design Thinking and Communication
courses.description: Integrated introduction to the user-centered design process and technical communication. Students will address current challenges experienced by project partners.  This course will guide students through identifying unmet needs, conducting research, generating and evaluating potential solutions, presenting a final design concept with supporting justification and documentation for design decisions.  Students will also enhance their abilities of contributing to an equitable team, project management, fabrication skills, and producing written, oral, graphical, and interpersonal communication. One lecture, two section meetings, and lab. Co-registration with ENGLISH 106-1 required. Primarily intended for first-year engineering students.

courses.name: Design Thinking and Communication
courses.description: Integrated iteration on the user-centered design process and technical communication. This course will build on the learning objectives from DTC-1 while adding more focus on ethics in design and communication, equitable distribution of teamwork, project management, documenting and communicating progress, and exploring a wider variety of project topics.  One lecture, two section meetings, and lab. Co-registration with ENGLISH 106-2 required. Primarily intended for first-year engineering students.

courses.name: Design Thinking and Doing
courses.description: Project-based introduction to design, structured as a hands-on studio course. Students learn methods of design innovation and work in teams, exploring ideas, prototyping solutions, and interacting with users. Intended for non-McCormick students.

courses.name: Introduction to Design Sketching
courses.description: Design sketching to increase one's skills as a basic but essential form of communication. It is the medium for preliminary ideation. Basic rules and skills in a design studio setting.

courses.name: Advanced Sketching
courses.description: Advanced sketching techniques. Further development of skills for the design studio setting.

courses.name: Introduction to Solid Modeling: Solidworks
courses.description: Solid modeling by creating three-dimensional shapes through two-dimensional sketches. Assemblies of individual parts. CAD modeling theory; modeling objects using different approaches for creating identical features. Lecture balanced with hands-on use of SolidWorks.

courses.name: Visual Thinking for Design
courses.description: Often times when we confront a new problem space we choose to build up our understanding through research, readings and lectures. Visual Thinking for Design will focus upon complementing this understanding through the use of visual stimulus. We will work with visual thinking methods to help expand our understanding of a problem space resulting in a greater generation of ideas and a more tangible organization of our thoughts. No formal prerequisites. DSGN 220-0, Intro to Sketching, and some experience with Adobe Photoshop would be helpful but not necessary.

courses.name: Introductory Topics in Design
