courses.name: Foundations of Learning in a New Language
courses.description: Historical, political, sociocultural, and educational practices that impact linguistically and culturally diverse learners in American schools.

courses.name: Problems in the Philosophy of Education
courses.description: Classical and modern philosophies of education. Text interpretation, analysis of ideas, argument construction; relationship of philosophy to educational issues. Students develop their own philosophy of education.

courses.name: Content Area Reading and Writing
courses.description: Theory and practical methods of reading methodology to enable teacher candidates to scaffold the literacy skills of English-language learners and students not reading at grade level.

courses.name: Critical Issues in Literacy
courses.description: Continues on the work in MS_ED 422-0 and TEACH_ED 322-0, delving deeply into critical literacy issues.

courses.name: Educating Exceptional Children
courses.description: Students with disabilities, including learning disabilities resulting from human development and/or accidents; understanding and application of approved emergency, educational, and rehabilitative activities; interrelationships with medical, health, and educational personnel.

courses.name: Dynamics of Middle School Curriculum
courses.description: Identifying and understanding the effects of middle school dynamics (principles, structures, and practices) on classroom learning and instruction. Focuses on the development and social problems of fifth through eighth graders.

courses.name: Early Adolescent Development and Intervention
courses.description: Interaction of physical, mental, and emotional health and the surrounding social environment of middle school students; developmental characteristics of early adolescence; the middle school teacher's role in assessment and referral.

courses.name: Instructional Design & Assessment
courses.description: Students will gain an overview of various approaches to curriculum design and instructional models, and will investigate several kinds of assessments, including formative and summative, and how those assessments are linked to instructional design, teaching and learning. Opportunities will be given to practice grading, providing good feedback, and managing a class assessment system.

courses.name: Learning and Teaching with Techology
courses.description: Theory and practice of designing school environments that integrate new technologies and media. Taught with LRN_SCI 338-0; may not receive credit for both courses.

courses.name: Special Topics in Teacher Education
courses.description: Advanced work on special topics.

courses.name: Methods & Techniques: World Languages
courses.description: Analysis of research, teaching methodologies, and literature related to the content area. Focuses on learning experiences, methods, and educational techniques appropriate for elementary, middle school, and high school students. Concurrent registration in TEACH_ED 378-0 or TEACH_ED 379-0 required.

courses.name: Methods & Techniques: English
courses.description: Analysis of research, teaching methodologies, and literature related to the content area. Learning experiences, methods, and educational techniques appropriate for high school students.

courses.name: Methods and Techniques: Secondary Mathematics
courses.description: See description for MS_ED 456-0.

courses.name: Methods and Techniques: Science
courses.description: See description for MS_ED 456-0.

courses.name: Methods & Techniques: Social Science
courses.description: See description for MS_ED 456-0.

courses.name: Middle Grades Methods & Techniques of Teaching: English
Middle Grades Methods & Techniques of Teaching: Mathematics
Middle Grades Methods & Techniques of Teaching: Science
Middle Grades Methods & Techniques of Teaching: Social Sciences
Topics in High School Math
courses.description: Content varies.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Teaching: Secondary Humanities
courses.description: Exploration of education theory in the seminar, plus 10 hours a week of fieldwork. Concurrent registration in the applicable methods and techniques course (TEACH_ED 355-0 - TEACH_ED 359-0) required.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Teaching: Secondary Math/Science
courses.description: See description for MS_ED 478-0.

courses.name: Student Teaching: Humanities
courses.description: Seminar and accompanying fulltime, 10-week internship involving intensive clinical experience and teaching under the supervision of a mentor.

courses.name: Student Teaching Seminar: Math/Science
courses.description: See description for TEACH_ED 388-0.

courses.name: Production in Context
courses.description: A combination of lecture, discussion, and production lab participation implementing the directing and design process of a theatrical production.

courses.name: Production Laboratory
courses.description: (0 units) Registration for students fulfilling production crew requirements.

courses.name: Theatre in Context: Introduction
courses.description: Introductory course that features lectures, discussion, creative assignments, theatre analysis, research, and guest artists.

courses.name: Theatre in Context: Analysis & Research
courses.description: Seminar that emphasizes theatre history, analysis, criticism, research, and writing skills.

courses.name: Voice for Performance
courses.description: The focus is on the development of vocal technique for the performer through work on body alignment, breathing, vocal placement, resonance and exploration of the sounds of English using the IPA (International Phonetic Alphabet).  Individual vocal problems are analyzed and remedial work prescribed.  Concentrates on developing the speaking voice using the sounds of English and their relationship to meaning through the use of poetry and selected text.  Open to theatre majors only.

courses.name: Basic Acting
courses.description: For non-majors. Introduction to the study of acting: sensory response, imagination, and characterization work leading to prepared scenes from selected plays.

courses.name: Fundamentals of Stage Directing
courses.description: An introductory course focusing on defining the role of the director, as well as practical strategies for work with text and actors.

courses.name: Introduction to Theatre Design
courses.description: Introduces the principles and elements of visual design as they relate to the theatre design areas of scenery, costume, and lighting. Applies these principles and elements to a play by creating scenery, costume, and lighting design ideas based on text analysis, point of view, and research in a production notebook format. Does not count toward the requirements for the theatre major. Course is a requirement and prerequisite for all 200-level design courses for the theatre minor.

courses.name: Design Process: Scene
courses.description: Development of stage design for the theatrical designer, from initial reading of the script to final design. Crew participation in department productions. 1. Scene design.

courses.name: Design Process: Costume
courses.description: Development of stage design for the theatrical designer, from initial reading of the script to final design. Crew participation in department productions. 2. Costume design.

courses.name: Design Process: Lighting
courses.description: Development of stage design for the theatrical designer, from initial reading of the script to final design. Crew participation in department productions. 3. Lighting design.

courses.name: Stage Makeup
courses.description: Theory and practice of stage makeup. Crew participation in department productions.

courses.name: Theatre Sound
courses.description: An introductory class in sound design for the theatre. Crew participation in department productions.

courses.name: Theatre for Young Audiences
courses.description: Selection, evaluation, direction, and production of plays for children.

courses.name: Special Topics in Theatre Studies
courses.description: Content varies. Studies of individual playwrights, national or regional theatres, historical periods, performace practices, or theoretical inquiries.

courses.name: Theatre History I: Pre-1650
courses.description: Survey of the theory and history of world theatre and drama before 1650.

courses.name: Theatre History II: Post 1650
courses.description: Survey of the theory and history of world theatre and drama after 1650.

courses.name: Topics in Shakespeare
courses.description: Critical study of Shakespeare's plays, theatrical culture, and theories and adaptations based on his work.

courses.name: Modern & Contemp Theatre: Modern
courses.description: Critical study of major dramatists, theories, and production styles. 1870-1920.

courses.name: Modern & Contemp Theatre: Contemporary
courses.description: Critical study of major dramatists, theories, and production styles. 1920-present.

courses.name: Theatre of the Americas
courses.description: Survey of theatre and drama of the Americas; examines relevance of plays, performances such as pageants and blackface minstrelsy, theatre companies, and their original contexts to their national identity.

courses.name: Intermediate Voice I
courses.description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire.  Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

courses.name: Intermediate Voice II
courses.description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire.  Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

courses.name: Intermediate Voice III
courses.description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire.  Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

courses.name: Music Theatre History
courses.description: Three-part course, covering the major movements in the histories of dance, opera, and musical comedy. Examination of artists and their works.

courses.name: Creating the Musical
courses.description: A large variety of topics courses designed to educate students on the various areas of musical creation. Topics will cover: lyric writing, song writing, book creation, score/scene creation, among others.

courses.name: Voice for Shakespeare
courses.description: The focus of the class is on the training and development of the actor's voice integrating the work in THEATRE 170-0 Voice for Performance with the focus on Shakespeare's heightened text. Students work to develop optimal pitch, vocal range, improve articulation, intonation and stress through the performance of Shakespeare's Sonnets, scenes, monologues and group work.

courses.name: Acting I
courses.description: 1. Basic concepts.

courses.name: Acting I
courses.description: 2. Dramatic imagination.

courses.name: Acting I
courses.description: 3. Dramatic characterization.

courses.name: Intro to Playwriting
courses.description: A course in which students read plays, complete writing exercises based on the reading, see plays off campus, and ultimately research and write the beginning of a full-length play of their own. The course is open to students in any major and writers of all levels.

courses.name: Introduction to Stage Management
courses.description: Preproduction, rehearsal, and technical rehearsal process of theatrical productions. Basic stage management tools taught in theory: assembling a production book, blocking, scheduling, communication, and cueing.

courses.name: Special Topics in Directing
courses.description: Studies wih Directing Faculty on special topics related to directing and theatrical forms.

courses.name: Advanced Stage Directing
courses.description: Studies in particular aspects of directing or in forms of theatre. Students will further develop practical and theoretical skills as directors.

courses.name: Text Analysis
courses.description: Seminar in analysis of dramatic texts as related to the problems of realized theatrical production.

courses.name: Advanced Design Process: Scene
courses.description: For advanced undergraduate set design students and graduate students studying scene design as a secondary area. Lectures and design projects.

courses.name: Advanced Design Process: Costume
courses.description: For advanced undergraduates studying costume design and graduate students studying costume design as a secondary area. Lectures and design projects.

courses.name: Advanced Design Process: Lighting
courses.description: For advanced undergraduate lighting design students and graduate students studying lighting design as a secondary area. Lectures and design projects.

courses.name: History of Costume and Decor
courses.description: Style and aesthetics of art, architecture, fashion, and decorative arts. Special emphasis on periods of theatrical production. Current topic will be listed in the quarterly class schedule. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Advanced Theatre Sound
courses.description: Planning and execution of sound for theatrical production; design of the actor's acoustical environment. Crew participation in department productions.

courses.name: Scene Painting
courses.description: Traditional and contemporary theory and practice of scene painting. Lecture and studio. Lab fee required.

courses.name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: Graphic Arts for the Stage Designer
courses.description: Techniques and materials of graphic communication for the stage designer. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: Rendering the Theatrical Space
courses.description: Techniques and materials of graphic communication for the stage designer. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: Rendering the Theatrical Figure
courses.description: Techniques and materials of graphic communication for the stage designer. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Drawing & Painting for the Theatre: Drafting
courses.description: Techniques and materials of graphic communication for the stage designer. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: Freehand Drawing
courses.description: Drawing and composition using a variety of drawing materials and media for scenery, costume, and lighting designers. Lecture and studio.

courses.name: Drawing and Painting for the Theatre: The Figure in Space
courses.description: Drawing and composition using a variety of drawing materials and media for scenery, costume, and lighting designers. Lecture and studio.

courses.name: Textile Arts and Crafts
courses.description: For advanced undergraduate and graduate students studying costume design. Topics may include fabric dying, fabric modification, wig ventilation, millinery construction, and yarn arts. May be repeated for credit with change of topic.

courses.name: Period Pattern Drafting and Draping
courses.description: Techniques of flat pattern drafting and advanced construction used to create historical garment patterns for the stage. 1. Flat patterns.

courses.name: Period Pattern Drafting and Draping
courses.description: Techniques of flat pattern drafting and advanced construction used to create historical garment patterns for the stage. 2. Draping.

courses.name: Period Pattern Drafting and Draping
courses.description: Techniques of flat pattern drafting and advanced construction used to create historical garment patterns for the stage. 3. Period patterns.

courses.name: Computer Graphics for the Theatre Artist
courses.description: Computer graphics for the stage designer. Investigation of available software programs and strategies for use in theatre. Current topic will be listed in the quarterly class schedule. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Lecture/laboratory. Crew participation in department productions may be required.

courses.name: The Art of Storytelling
courses.description: Ancient traditions and current renaissance of storytelling. Strategies for selecting, preparing, and sharing stories in performance. Applications in theatre, communication, education, religion, law, healing professions, leadership, and business. 1. Basic techniques. Students use storytelling in presentations and performance.

courses.name: Advanced Storytelling
courses.description: Ancient traditions and current renaissance of storytelling. Strategies for selecting, preparing, and sharing stories in performance. Applications in theatre, communication, education, religion, law, healing professions, leadership, and business. 2. Advanced techniques of research, preparation, and performance, culminating in a public event. Students use storytelling in presentations and performance.

courses.name: Creative Drama
courses.description: Applications of creative drama in many areas (e.g., teaching, performance, therapy, writing, recreation). Students explore the use of process-centered improvisations in their lives and work.

courses.name: Advanced Creative Drama
courses.description: Explores improvised drama as a teaching method and a means of learning for the elementary school child. Theory and practice through reading, discussion, films, and observation. Course culminates in extended teaching projects with children from local schools.

courses.name: Special Topics in Advanced Theatre Studies
courses.description: Content varies. Advanced study of individual playwrights, practitioners, regional theatres, historical periods, performance practices, or theoretical inquiries.

courses.name: Theatre and Social Change
courses.description: Prerequisite: THEATRE 140-1, THEATRE 140-2 or consent of instructor.

courses.name: Dramaturgy
courses.description: Seminar in creative dramaturgical research as it relates to the problems of realized theatrical production.

courses.name: Puppetry History & Performance
courses.description: Seminar in the history and theory of puppetry with an emphasis on embodied experimentation.

courses.name: Gender & Performance
courses.description: Exploration of recent research on the social and political background of gender, particularly women's access to performative expressions. Historical aesthetics: changing debates on women's participation in the public theatre and the significance of the body in performance.

courses.name: African American Theatre
courses.description: Study of African American playwrights, practitioners, theatre companies, historical performance practices, theoretical inquiries, or transnational infuences.

courses.name: Asian American Theatre
courses.description: Study of Asian American playwrights, practitioners, theatre companies, historical performance practices, theoretical inquiries, or transnational infuences.

courses.name: Latinx Theatre
courses.description: Study of Latinx playwrights, practitioners, theatre companies, historical performance practices, theoretical inquiries, or transnational infuences.

courses.name: Transnational Theatre
courses.description: Study of the history, theory, or literature of transnational theatre and other performance forms.

courses.name: Advanced Voice I
courses.description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire.    Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire.  Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

courses.name: Advanced Voice II
courses.description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire.    Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire.  Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

courses.name: Advanced Voice III
courses.description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire.    Performances at studio class, juries and special topics classes required. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, improve confidence for performance and application of technique to repertoire.  Students continue to build musicianship skills and their understanding and assimilation of vocal technique.

courses.name: Advanced Voice IV
courses.description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing, to build endurance and stamina, and help you to transition into your professional singing career. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, perfecting cuts for optimum singing performance, vocal reliability, vocal health,  and application of technique to repertoire. This year long curriculum will culminate in a capstone experience.

courses.name: Advanced Voice V
courses.description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing, to build endurance and stamina, and help you to transition into your professional singing career. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, perfecting cuts for optimum singing performance, vocal reliability, vocal health,  and application of technique to repertoire. This year long curriculum will culminate in a capstone experience.

courses.name: Advanced Voice VI
courses.description: Private instruction in vocal musical theatre technique and repertoire. The primary course objective is to improve your individual instrument and approach to singing, to build endurance and stamina, and help you to transition into your professional singing career. Emphasis in lessons will be placed upon strengthening technique, perfecting cuts for optimum singing performance, vocal reliability, vocal health,  and application of technique to repertoire. This year long curriculum will culminate in a capstone experience.

courses.name: Advanced Music Theatre Techniques I
courses.description: Various performance styles of musical theatre. Current topic will be listed in the quarterly class schedule. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Instructor consent required.

courses.name: Advanced Music Theatre Techniques II
courses.description: Various performance styles of musical theatre. Current topic will be listed in the quarterly class schedule. May be repeated for credit with change of topic. Instructor consent required.

courses.name: Musical Theatre Techniques for Non-Music Theatre Cert
Advanced Creating the Musical
courses.description: A large variety of advanced topics courses designed to educate students on the various areas of musical creation. Topics will cover: lyric writing, song writing, book creation, score/scene creation, amoung others.

courses.name: Advanced Musicianship for Actors: Theatre Styles and Genres
Standing Down Straight for Actors
courses.description: Standing Down Straight® for Actors is a holistic, universally applicable voice-and-movement technique for theatre students. Students explore using natural speech patterns and natural movement patterns as the basis of all stage expression.  Thus, in class exercises, monologues, and partnered scenes, they explore using gravity-directed relaxation as a way to calm body and mind - so that both body and mind can work with power, intensity, and without strain.

courses.name: Advanced Voice Styles
courses.description: Advanced vocal techniques for the stage actor.  Vocal styles including performing the plays of language and heightened text using texts of Molière, Oscar Wilde, Bernard Shaw, Noël Coward, Tom Stoppard.

courses.name: Acting II: Analysis and Performance
courses.description: Theory, principles, and techniques of interpretation of drama from the actor's point of view. 1. tragedy.

courses.name: Acting II: Analysis and Performance
courses.description: Theory, principles, and techniques of interpretation of drama from the actor's point of view. 2. verse.

courses.name: Acting II: Analysis and Performance
courses.description: Theory, principles, and techniques of interpretation of drama from the actor's point of view. 3. realism.

courses.name: Dialects for the Stage
courses.description: Using the International Phonetic Alphabet, dialect recordings and selected text, students are given the tools to acquire a variety of dialects for performance in theatre and film.  Principal dialects covered are standard British (Received Pronunciation), Cockney, Irish (North and South), French, Russian, German, American Southern and New York.

courses.name: Advanced Acting Topics
courses.description: Special Topics for advanced senior actors explore complex forms of theatrical performance, technique, style, and cultural aspects an educated actor must consider and implement.

courses.name: Intro to Acting for the Screen
Topics in Acting for the Screen
courses.description: Foundational concerns and practices for screen-specific acting.  Scenic analysis, rehearsal, staging and camera space, casting, editing for performance. Creating and portraying characters for most effective capture by the camera. Film directing techniques as related to the actor. Required introductory course for the Acting for the Screen module sequence.

courses.name: Diagnostic Scene Study for the Screen
courses.description: Retrospective critique of curricular and extracurricular performance work in the Acting for Screen module.  Evaluation of performer's range and capabilities in terms of future projects and identity as an actor.  Relationship between actor and director relative to the camera.  Required course for the module.

courses.name: Advanced Playwriting Sequence
courses.description: Fundamental techniques of playwriting: a yearlong sequence aimed at developing original, full-length play.

courses.name: Advanced Playwriting Sequence
courses.description: Fundamental techniques of playwriting. A yearlong sequence aimed at developing an original full-length play.

courses.name: Advanced Playwriting Sequence
courses.description: Fundamental techniques of playwriting. A yearlong sequence aimed at developing an original full-length play.

courses.name: Advanced Stage Management
courses.description: Problem solving in the stage manager¿s leadership role; advanced study in production realization and communication. Students will be required to stage manage or assistant stage manage a department production and will prepare a production book based on the production.

courses.name: Production Management
courses.description: Production Management roles and responsibilites, production budgets, timelines and building and leading production team.

courses.name: Internship in Theatre Practice
courses.description: Practice (3 units for undergraduates; 2 units for graduates) Production and/or management activities in a theatre company. Application required.

courses.name: Theatre Practicum
courses.description: Research, teaching, and/or production assistance in collaboration with departmental faculty. The aim of the practicum is for students to learn about theatrical education, research, or artistic process through applied practice rather than through traditional coursework (including independent study) or external professional opportunities (internships, apprenticeships, etc.). A student may take up to 4 credits of CMN 340-0 or THEATRE 395-0. One credit of CMN 340-0, THEATRE 395-0 may count towards the major requirements; the remaining three will be applied to Elective credit.

courses.name: Theatre Management and Arts Leadership
courses.description: Exploring and understanding the Artistic and Business leadership and parnternship  in the Commerical and not for profit theatre communities.

courses.name: Theatre Marketing
courses.description: Partnering with the Broadway in Chicago, students will interview and be placed into marketing teams to market a new musical.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Prerequisite: consent of undergraduate dean after submission of petition.

courses.name: Seminar in Transportation and Logistics
courses.description: Yearlong senior seminar on the structure of the transportation and supply-chain industries and evaluation of relevant public policy. Students receive 1 credit in the spring quarter of their senior year.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Advanced work chosen by mutual agreement with a faculty member. Only 1 unit may count toward the minor. Consent of faculty required.

courses.name: Turkish I
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing. Offers students a systematic introduction to Turkish language and culture. Print and audiovisual materials used to supplement textbook.

courses.name: Turkish I
courses.description: This sequence emphasizing the four modalities-speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing. Offers students a systematic introduction to Turkish language and culture. Print and audiovisual materials used to supplement textbook.

courses.name: Turkish I

courses.name: Turkish II
courses.description: This sequence further develops speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing, through the use of printed and audiovisual materials in Turkish. Offers insights into modern Turkish culture.

courses.description: This sequence further develops speaking, listening comprehension, reading, and writing, through the use of printed and audiovisual materials in Turkish. Offers insights into modern Turkish culture.

courses.name: Turkish II

courses.description: Lessons consist of individual instruction, with each student receiving the equivalent of 50 minutes of instruction weekly.

courses.description: Lessons consist of individual instruction, with each student receiving the equivalent of 50 minutes of instruction weekly.

courses.name: Vocal Solo Class
courses.description: Weekly recital hour. Required for any student registered for full-credit private voice lessons.

courses.name: Vocal Pedagogy for Undergraduates
courses.description: The fundamentals of vocal production, including laryngeal anatomy, posture, breathing, resonance, articulation, and registration. Topics also include health care of the professional voice and some pathologies of the vocal folds.

courses.name: Selected Topics in Voice
courses.description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May include chanson, recitative, and non-English languages. May be repeated.

courses.name: Undergraduate Opera Workshop I
courses.description: Advanced techniques for the performance of arias; methods of text and character analysis; audition techniques; study of opera scenes.

courses.name: Undergraduate Opera Workshop II

courses.description: Advanced techniques for the performance of arias; methods of text and character analysis; audition techniques; study of opera scenes.

courses.name: Opera Performance

courses.name: Professional Preparation For Singers
courses.description: Designed to help the aspiring singer make the leap into professional work. Covers the musical, physical, and business aspects of being a professional musician. Includes teaching by guest artists.

courses.name: Repertoire Studies
courses.description: Topics vary by quarter and may include the German Lied, chanson, oratorio repertoire, and recitative.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Permission of instructor and department required.

Applied French Horn for Music Majors
Applied French Horn for Music Majors
Selected Topics
courses.description: Topics vary; announced before registration. May be repeated.

courses.description: Methods, materials, and writings related to percussion playing and teaching.

courses.name: Repertoire Studies
courses.description: Includes winds/brass/percussion orchestral repertoire, clarinet orchestral studies, and studies in woodwind and brass literature.

courses.name: Introduction to Yiddish Culture: Images of the Shtetl
courses.description: Analysis and discussion of the literary, visual, and filmic images of the communal life developed by Eastern European Jews and inseparably associated with them. GERMAN 266-0, JWSH_ST 266-0 and YIDDISH 266-0 taught together; students may receive credit for only one of these.

courses.name: Yiddish Culture and the Holocaust
courses.description: Analysis of modern Yiddish literature before the Holocaust as well as literary work that emerged from Yiddish-speaking writers who survived the Second World War. GERMAN 366-0, JWSH_ST 366-0 and YIDDISH 366-0 taught together; may receive credit for only one course.

courses.name: Independent Study
courses.description: Prerequisite: Consent of instructor.
